  3. Luminous Glow: Emit a soothing glow that heals allies. As a half-action, heal an ally within short range for [[1d4]] + your Spirit check. This glow can also dispel shadows, countering mild magical darkness.
  4. Twilight Perception: Gain advantage on Observation checks at night. On success+, spot invisible enemies. Amplifies your Solar Flare to deal [[1d6]] Solar damage in addition to blinding the target.
  5. Umbra Step: (Agility +2, Stealth +2, Spirit +2, Observation +2) Enhance your Eclipse Dash. When teleporting, leave behind a shadow clone that distracts attacking creatures within reach, granting them disadvantage on their next attack.
  6. Dark Dash: When you use Eclipse Dash and end your turn within melee range of an enemy, you can make an attack action.
  7. Telepathic Understanding: If a creature speaks to another telepathically, you can also hear it and know their location, no matter how far or how well they try to hide.
  8. Solar Radiance: Channel the full strength of sunlight to bolster allies. As an action, grant yourself and up to 6 creatures 10 Solar Armor that lasts for 1 minute. This ability cannot be used again for 1 hour.
  9. Lunar Guidance: (Agility +3, Stealth +3, Spirit +3, Observation +3) When you use Tactical Awareness on a creature at night, they emit a glow, giving all allies advantage on strikes against them for 1 minute. If the creature flees, you can track them until you take a short or long rest.
  10. Eclipse Resurgence: As your ultimate ability, once per long rest, embody the perfect balance of light and darkness for 1 minute.
    • Your Eclipse Dash leaves a twilight trail that allies can use to double their movement speed.
    • Your Solar Flare and Midnight Cloak abilities affect all enemies or allies within medium range.
Talents

Talents for Professionals underscore your combat style and strategic acumen. These are the distinguishing traits that set your approach to battle apart, be it unmatched prowess with a specific weapon or a unique battlefield tactic.

Dragonkeeper

The Dragonkeeper is a rare and revered master of elemental pseudo-dragons, forming bonds with these scaled companions to unleash their latent power. As a Dragonkeeper, you nurture and train your draconic ally, transforming it into a loyal and versatile companion. Whether commanding their elemental breath in the heat of battle or relying on their keen senses and unique abilities to overcome challenges, the Dragonkeeper wields the raw force of nature embodied in their dragon. Together, you become an unstoppable duo, blending strategy, power, and the unbreakable bond of dragon and keeper.

Chroma Dragon

Your Chroma Dragon is a loyal companion, a PL2 pseudo-dragon capable of shifting between elemental affinities. It has a reach range line attack dealing [[1d6]] elemental damage and can act independently on your turn.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Elemental Harmony: Your Chroma Dragon's elemental attacks deal an additional +2 damage. As an action, you can switch its elemental affinity to adapt to the battlefield.
  • Winged Ally: Your Chroma Dragon gains a fly speed equal to its movement speed and can carry small objects or provide aerial reconnaissance.
  • Empowered Breath: Enhance your Chroma Dragon's breath attack. Its reach increases to short range and its damage increases to [[2d6]] elemental damage.
  • Shared Senses: As an off-action, you can see and hear through your dragon’s senses until the end of your next turn, gaining advantage on Observation checks during this time.
  • Draconic Resilience: Your Chroma Dragon gains +10 armor and +10 wounds, making it more resilient in battle.
  • Chroma Tail Whip: As an off-action, your Chroma Dragon can make a [[1d4]] tail attack.
  • Elemental Synergy: While within short range of your Chroma Dragon, your melee or ranged attacks deal an additional +2 damage of your dragon’s current elemental type.
  • Elemental Surge: once per long rest, your Chroma Dragon can unleash a powerful elemental surge in a wide cone, dealing [[4d6]] elemental damage and inflicting a corpus condition. Enemies must make a Survival check, halving the damage per success.
  • Bonded Fury: When your Chroma Dragon takes damage, you can spend a Champion Point to grant both you and your dragon advantage on your next attack rolls until the end of your next turn.
  • Elder Dragon Form: Your Chroma Dragon transforms into a PL4 elder pseudo-dragon for 1 minute. It gains increased size, double damage, medium range attacks, and immunity to its current elemental type. Once this ability is used, it cannot be activated again until after a long rest.
Ghostborn

As a Ghostborn, you exist between the mortal and ethereal planes. You have the ability to phase through objects, move unseen and unheard, and are practically a ghost to those around you. However, you are haunted by phantom pains of a body that is no longer yours, making it difficult to fully embrace your ethereal nature.

Ethereal Travel

As an action, gain the intangible condition. If you pass through a creature while in this condition, the creature takes [[1d4]] thunder damage. As an action on a following turn, you can remove the intangible condition.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Spectral Agility: When you take the Dash action, you become invisible until the end of your next turn unless you make another action of any type.
  • Ghost Touch: Your weapons deal an additional +2 psychic damage. Additionally, you can use Ethereal Travel as a half-action.
  • Shadowborn: You no longer suffer half movement from the intangible condition, and you can deal half damage to creatures that aren't intangible.
  • Spectral Grasp: You can interact with objects and cast spells while intangible. In addition, your spells have full effect on incorporeal or ethereal creatures.
  • Ethereal Evasion: As a reaction, become partially intangible, taking half damage from a single attack.
  • Revenant Recovery: When you gain the intangible condition, you heal [[1d4]].
  • Haunting Translocation: You are permanently between planes. Gain +5 armor and you are semi-translucent, but you cast more shadows than normal. The souls of the Umbral Eclipse whisper and distract you.
  • Ghostly Veil: As an action, bring up to 6 allies into the Umbral Eclipse or out. Alternatively, as an action, shroud up to 6 creatures in shadows, giving them +2 to stealth checks.
  • Revenant Ascension: Embrace your ghostly heritage fully. Gain a fly speed equal to your movement while in the Umbral Eclipse.
  • Veil of the Whispers: As a half-action, become empowered by the eclipse, preventing the next condition applied to you until the end of your next turn.
Gunslinger

As a Gunslinger, you are a master of firearms and have honed your skills in the art of shooting to perfection. You possess an extensive knowledge of guns and are always equipped with the necessary ammunition to carry out your job effectively. With your steady aim and quick reflexes, you are a force to be reckoned with on the battlefield.

Sharpshooter

When you make a called shot to cause a condition, the penalty is -6 instead of -10.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Burst Fire: You have trained extensively to improve your rate of fire. As part of an attack action, when you make an attack with a firearm, make another attack at disadvantage.
  • Marked for Death: When you use Tactical Assessment on a creature, gain +3 to attack checks and damage on that creature.
  • Quickdraw Showdown: You've mastered the art of the quickdraw. As an action, you can challenge an enemy to a quickdraw duel. Both of you make an attack roll; whoever makes a lower check takes the charmed or fear condition with the other as the source.
  • Deft Reload: You've become exceptionally quick at reloading firearms. Reload as a free action. Additionally, make an Influence check to impress or intimidate creatures in or out of combat by reloading skillfully.
  • Tough as Nails: This rough life has toughened you up. Gain +1 to all checks.
  • Armored Shooter: Your extensive training has taught you how to fire your weapons effectively while wearing armor. You no longer take penalties for wearing any armor.
  • Shot on the Run: When you take the Dash action, make an attack with a firearm at disadvantage.
  • Lead Storm: Unleash a torrent of bullets on your enemies. Make two attack actions with firearms. Afterward, you take the deaf condition for 1 hour.
  • Powerful Gunslinger: Reach the pinnacle of gunslinging. Your critical hit range with firearms increases to 18.
  • High Noon: As an action, declare "High Noon." On your next turn, your first ranged attack is an automatic critical hit and a Success+++.
Investigator

The Noir Detective is a sharp-eyed investigator and master of urban intrigue, skilled in navigating shadowy alleys, uncovering hidden truths, and outwitting opponents. Using a mix of deductive prowess, quirky gadgets, and street smarts, they uncover mysteries and manipulate the odds in their favor.

Mystic Deduction

You harness the power of deduction and perception to cast spells that reveal truths, manipulate the environment, or influence others. Your Observation Check determines your spellcasting check. You have Spell Points equal to your Observation Check.

Instinctive Insight

As an off-action spending 1 spell point, gain advantage on checks to detect lies, uncover clues, or sense hidden motives.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Lucky Break: As an off-action spending 1 spell point, reroll a failed Investigation, Observation, or Spirit check.
  • Mechanical Assistant: As an action spending 1 spell point, deploy a small gadget (e.g., a clockwork insect or bird) to perform surveillance, deliver a message, or retrieve a light object that lasts 1 hour.
  • Hidden Contact: As an action spend one spell point and speak with a hidden ally in the area that can provide information or provide some other minor assistance such as relaying information, distracting enemies, or retrieving small items.
  • Interrogation: As an action spending 1 spell point targeting a creature within short range, make a contested Observation check. If you succeed, they must reveal 1 piece of information and suffer disadvantage on Influence checks until the end of their next turn.
  • Flash Disruptor: As an off-action, use a gadget to blind a target. They must make an Observation check or take the blind condition until the end of their next turn.
  • Identify: As an action, spend 1 spell point to analyze an object and learn a key fact about its history, such as its last user, origin, any curses it may contain, or a hidden property about the object.
  • Smoke Bomb: As an action, spend 1 spell point to create dense fog in a short-range area at a point within short range, granting disadvantage to attacks for all creatures in the fog until the end of your next turn. Increase duration by 1 round with additional spell points.
  • Hidden Whisper: Whisper a message to a creature within medium range that only they can hear. If the creature is hostile, they must make a Spirit check or become distracted, granting you or an ally advantage on your next attack action targeting them.
  • Deciphering Lens: As an action spending 1 spell point, automatically succeed on a check to decode messages, read faded text, briefly understand a dead language, or identify obscure symbols.
  • Wiretap: As an action spending 1 spell point, place a discreet listening device on a surface or object. You can hear any conversations or noises near the object as long as you remain within medium range.
Soulblade

As a Soulblade, you possess the rare ability to summon weapons from within yourself. You are a master of harnessing the power of your soul to create weapons of incredible strength and durability. Your weapons are a reflection of your innermost self and are imbued with your unique energy.

Soul Weapon

As an off-action summon a powerful melee weapon made entirely of your soul energy that requires an Agility, Strength, or Spirit check to wield. The weapon deals [[1d8]] physical damage and lasts for 1 minute. If you stop touching the weapon, it dissipates immediately.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Soul Reflection: As an off-action when you make an attack with your soul weapon, you can make another attack on the same creature or one within range.
  • Soul Guard: At the start of combat, gain [[2d6]] armor.
  • Harmonic Resonance: As a 1-minute action, you can change your soul weapon’s damage type to any Elemental type. Once you do this, you cannot do it again for 1 minute.
  • Soul Reach: Your soul weapon can become a ranged weapon instead of melee.
  • Dual Soul Formation: When you make an attack on a creature with your soul weapon, you deal 1 damage of your chosen type to all creatures of your choice within your melee range.
  • Soul Aegis: As a half-action, your soul energy can now coalesce into a protective shield around an ally, granting them [[1d6]] armor for 1 minute.
  • Tactical Soul: When you have used Tactical Assessment on a creature, you can read their surface-level thoughts and have advantage on social checks against them.
  • Soul Echo: As an action, you create a spectral duplicate of yourself that can take a turn on your next turn in combat. It exists until the end of your next turn.
  • Soul Empowerment: The bond between you and your soul weapon grows stronger. Your soul weapon deals [[2d8]] damage.
  • Soul Bond: As a 1-minute action, you can create a telepathic link with an ally, allowing silent communication over any distance for 1 hour.
Steadfast

Walk the path where honor is your shield and resolve your sword. Embody the unyielding spirit of the warrior, standing resolute against all odds. In the tumult of war, you are the calm within the storm. Your talent as a soldier is not just a skill; it is an intrinsic part of who you are. You read the battlefield as a maestro reads a symphony, each movement a note, each strategy a chord. Your instincts, honed by countless skirmishes, allow you to anticipate enemy tactics, turning their maneuvers to your advantage with uncanny precision.

Awareness Stance

When you take this stance as a half-action, you can use your off-action to make an opportunity attack at advantage against any creature that enters your melee weapon range.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Steadfast Resolve: While in the Awareness Stance, you are immune to the fear condition.
  • Battlefield Tactician: Your tactical acumen allows you to exploit enemy weaknesses. When you use Tactical Assessment on an enemy, you and your allies gain a +2 bonus to their attack checks against that enemy while Tactical Assessment is active.
  • Silent Storm Approach: Learn to blend stealth and speed, striking unexpectedly and with deadly efficiency. You can take the Hide action while you Disengage.
  • Defensive Harmony: When you take the Awareness Stance, gain [[12]] armor. Additionally, you can hold 2 stances at once.
  • Zenith Focus: Achieve a heightened state of focus. When you take the Awareness Stance, you can hear invisible creatures and treat them as not being invisible.
  • Awareness II: When you take the Awareness Stance, give enemies Disadvantage to hit you.
  • Indomitable Spirit: When you take the Awareness Stance, you are immune to Corpus Conditions until the start of your next turn.
  • Wind Cutter Technique: You can take the Awareness Stance as an Off-Action. After taking the Awareness Stance, you can attack 2 times on your next turn when you take the attack action.
  • Step of the Wind: You are wind incarnate. You can Dash as a half-action.
  • Steadfast Gambit: Unleash the full extent of your training and inner power in a single, decisive action. As an action, you become a blur to all creatures, making [[1d10+1]] attacks on any creature within medium range or on a single creature. Upon using this ability, you take the Exhausted, Stunned, and Confused conditions for [[1d4]] rounds.
Thornweaver

As a Thornweaver, you have an unparalleled connection to the world of plants, particularly those with defensive and offensive capabilities. Your ability to manipulate thorns, vines, and other flora allows you to protect your allies, control the battlefield, and strike fear into the hearts of your enemies.

Vine Trap

As an action, place a Vine trap within reach range that triggers when an enemy steps on it, causing [[2d6]] piercing damage and the pinned condition until the end of your next turn. The trap lasts until removed or triggered.

Thorn Lash

As an action, make a Strength or Agility check targeting up to three enemies within short range, dealing [[1d6]] piercing damage to each on a success.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Thorn Stance: As a half-action, take the Thorn Stance. When a creature hits you with a melee attack, deal half the damage back to them as piercing damage.
  • Thornshot: As an action, make a ranged attack within medium range, dealing [[2d6]] physical damage and causing the bleeding condition.
  • Living Thorn Armor: As an action, give you and an ally within reach range living armor that provides +5 armor.
  • Poison Thorns: As an off-action, enhance your attacks to deal an additional [[3]] toxic damage and inflict the coughing condition on enemies until the end of your next turn.
  • Thorn Lash II: Your Thorn Lash can target up to 6 enemies and deals an additional +3 damage.
  • Thorned Ground: Transform a short range around you into difficult terrain that remains for 1 minute. Enemies moving through it take [[1d6]] piercing damage each time they enter your Thorned Ground.
  • Speak with Plants: Gain the ability to speak Naech (Plants), allowing you to gather information about the surrounding area or ask plants to perform simple tasks.
  • Floral Ward: Bloom with flowers as an action. Allies within reach range are immune to the charmed and confused conditions. This aura lasts for 1 minute or until you dismiss it.
  • Camouflage: As an off-action, gain advantage on Stealth checks until the end of your next turn. If in a natural environment, become invisible.
  • Herbal Remedy: As an action, heal an ally within reach range for [[2d6]] healing or remove one non-major condition. If in a natural environment, heal additional [[1d6]] wounds.
Trapper

As a Tricky Trapper, you specialize in setting traps and creating diversions to give your team the upper hand in combat. You are a master of deception and misdirection, always looking for ways to outsmart your opponents. With your expertise in disarming and stealing traps, you can turn the tables on your enemies in the blink of an eye.

Trapper Points

As an action, set a trap within reach range. The trap remains until triggered or disarmed. Traps have a range of (5 ft) trigger radius and can be spotted with an Observation check.

Trap Types

  • Snare Trap: Immobilizes the target, causing the pinned condition.
  • Explosive Trap: Deals [[2d4]] fire damage to the target and creatures within 5 ft.
  • Poison Trap: Deals [[1d6]] toxic damage and inflicts the coughing condition.
  • Alarm Trap: Emits a loud noise when triggered, alerting allies and startling enemies.
  • Healing Trap: Heals the first ally to trigger it for [[2d6]] healing.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Quick Setup: Reduce the time it takes to set up a trap to a half-action and increase the trigger range of your traps by +5 ft.
  • Snare Trap II: Your snare trap also causes the Bleeding condition.
  • Trap Engineer: Your traps gain +5 ft trigger range and deal an additional +2 damage.
  • Silent Setup: You've become adept at setting up traps stealthily. Enemies no longer get an opportunity to spot you setting up traps or to see the traps themselves.
  • Explosive Trap II: Explosion trap deals damage to creatures within 20 ft.
  • Trap Persistence: Even when triggered, your traps stay operational, able to be triggered a second time, the first time a creature enters their range and at the end of their next turn.
  • Autonomous Traps: Your traps can move to a new location and set themselves. You can command your traps on your turn. Your traps have a chance to be spotted when they move.
  • Unparalleled Trapper: Your skill in trapping is unsurpassed. You can now set up traps as an off-action.
  • Healing Trap II: Healing trap can also remove a Corpus condition.
  • Calamity Trap: You create a single trap that takes 1 hour. It has the ability to wreak havoc on the battlefield, triggering a terrain-altering effect when sprung (e.g., obscuring mist, difficult terrain, stonequake, avalanche, tornado, etc.). The effect is handled by the narrator and lasts for 1 minute.
Support

As the quintessential support specialist, this class is the embodiment of both the moral compass guiding their allies toward righteous victories and the sinner's wingman, offering redemption and support in their quest for atonement. This character thrives in the role of empowering and protecting their comrades, utilizing a keen understanding of both the battlefield and the human spirit.

Masters of both strategy and empathy, they harness a diverse array of abilities to shield friends from harm, enhance their fighting capabilities, and disrupt foes with tactical acumen. Beyond the tangible benefits of healing and bolstering defenses, they inspire greatness in their allies, lifting their spirits in the darkest times and offering guidance when moral dilemmas cloud the path forward.

Class Features & Equipment

Features

  • Inspiration: You have a Class Resource of 5 Inspirations that recover 1 on a Press On or all of them on a long rest. These can also be recovered through significant role-playing moments, critical successes in support actions, or achieving personal or group milestones related to your character or party.

    • As an action spending 1 point or a half-action/off-action for 2 points, you can touch a creature and choose an effect. However, you cannot remove a permanent condition or effect:

    • Give a creature up to 10 points of healing.
    • Give a creature 10 armor that remains until the end of their next turn.
    • Remove 1 condition.
    • Grant advantage to their next check.
    • Reduce a curse or disease.
  • Unhindered Movement: Needing the ability to get to those you care for, your movement does not provoke opportunity attacks, and you can also fall from a short range without taking damage.

Equipment

  • Traveler's Cloak: (7 armor, Observation +1, Survival +1)
  • Choose:
    • Standard Weapon: (Agi or Str; 1 hand, Light; [[1d6]] Physical)
    • Standard Pistol: (Check (Agi, Lck, Str, Obs); medium range, 1 hand, light; [[1d4!]] Piercing)
    • Small Weapon: (Agility; 1 Hand, Light, Hidden, Throwing Range: Short; [[1d4]] Physical)
Paths

The Support's path is a sanctified journey of restoration and aid. Each level unlocks greater healing powers and abilities to protect and rejuvenate your allies, symbolizing your growth from a caretaker to a guardian of life.

Boneclad

As a Necrotic Caregiver, you walk a delicate line between life and death, channeling the powers of the afterlife to heal and protect your allies while siphoning strength from the souls of the departed. Your role is to empower your comrades through both restorative necromancy and the tactical manipulation of life force. You bolster your party by weaving between the boundaries of the living and the dead, granting aid in unexpected ways and ensuring that even in death, there is utility. Unlike traditional necromancers, you serve as both a healer and a protector, turning the energies of decay into a force for good.

Wraithform

As an action, shroud yourself and an ally in a ghostly aura, granting advantage on stealth checks. Your Spirit Check is your spellcasting modifier, and you have Spell Points equal to your Spirit Check.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).
  • Gain +1 Spell Point at each of these levels.

Progression Steps

  1. Pale Resurrection: Temporarily raise a creature that has taken the death condition as a wraith to fight for [[1d4]] rounds, spending 3 spell points. They can’t speak but retain their combat abilities.
  2. Bone Spear: As an action, target a creature within medium range with a spellcasting check.
  3. Life Drain: As an action, make a ranged spell attack against a creature within range. On a hit, deal [[3d6]] eclipse damage and heal for half the damage dealt. Add 1 spell point to deal an additional +2 damage per spell point used.
  4. Bone Legion: As an action spending 3 spell points, summon a swarm of [[1d10]] PL0 skeletal warriors for [[1d4]] rounds to attack enemies within short range.
  5. Spectral Link: Connect the life force of two allies. Whenever either of them takes damage, it's halved and split between each.
  6. Soul-Sworn Bond: Link your soul with an ally, granting them advantage on all checks, but when they make a check you take [[1d6]] psychic damage.
  7. Haunting Gaze: Spend 2 spell points to lock eyes with an enemy, stunning them with visions of death and forcing them to make a Spirit check or be stunned for 1 round.
  8. Bonebound Aegis: Summon a wall of spectral bones that grants cover to allies and absorbs [[2d6]] damage per ally behind it, spending 4 spell points.
  9. Grave Swarm: As an action spending 2 spell points, raise a horde of decomposed hands from the ground, pinning all enemies in a medium range area for [[1d6]] rounds.
  10. Requiem of the Fallen: You offer yourself as a conduit for the dead, allowing Zuinmuir to momentarily return all fallen allies to life through your sacrifice. You sacrifice yourself to resurrect all allies who have died within the last 24 hours. They return to life with full health, free of conditions, and are empowered by the god of death, granting them advantage on all checks for the next minute. Once the spell concludes, you die, your soul delivered to Zuinmuir as a faithful servant.
Careward

The Careward embodies the heart of compassion and ingenuity, serving as a lifeline for their allies and a bridge between realms. They wield a rare gift: the ability to conjure sanctuaries that transcend the physical plane. These sanctuaries are not merely safe havens but also spaces of creativity, collaboration, and possibility, where the party can regroup, heal, and prepare for the challenges ahead. The Careward’s sanctuaries are as versatile as they are personal. These demi-planes reflect the Careward’s imagination, ranging from serene gardens to arcane workshops or even bustling miniature cities. Within these sanctuaries, allies can rest in safety, collaborate on projects, and recover from the tolls of battle, while the Careward remains at the center of this dynamic haven, guiding and inspiring those who enter.

Sanctuary

As an action, spend 1 Inspiration to create a door to a small sanctuary that lasts for 10 minutes. Spend 2 Inspirations for a Press On or 3 for a long rest. Your sanctuary is a shared space with living creatures, but you choose the theme of the sanctuary you create. The space is a small singular room that fits your party comfortably. Creatures cannot remain in your sanctuary while you are not there.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).
  • Gain +1 Class Resource at each of these levels.

Progression Steps

  1. Planar Strike: As an action, spend 1 Inspiration to make a Spirit check on a creature within short range and deal [[1d6+3]] Thunder damage on a success as you tear the realm around them.
  2. Planar Guide: You can recognize when creatures are from another plane of existence. As an action, spend 1 Inspiration to open a portal to a creature's native plane, which stays open until the end of your next turn.
  3. Sanctuary Guardian: You have a guardian in your sanctuary that is a PL3. They can leave your sanctuary for 1 minute but must hibernate or deactivate for 1 hour afterward.
  4. Sanctuary Recall: As a half-action while in your Sanctuary, spend 1 Inspiration to instantly recall a willing ally to your Sanctuary, regardless of distance. Allies in your sanctuary receive +1 healing per minute while in your sanctuary.
  5. Sanctuary II: Your Sanctuary becomes larger and inhabited by creatures of your choice that can work on simple tasks. Spend 3 Inspirations per complex task (e.g., repairing armor, crafting weapons, making potions). Tasks are completed successfully but not to an impressive level.
  6. Impressive Inspiration: You can target 2 creatures with your Inspirations simultaneously, but they must be within touch range.
  7. Planar Strike II: Increase the damage of your Planar Strike to [[3d6+3]] elemental damage of your choice. On a successful hit, spend 1 Inspiration to send the creature to your Sanctuary. While there, they must make an Influence check; on a failure, they remain for 1 minute and have the charmed condition with you as the source.
  8. Planar Guide II: As an action, spend 1 Inspiration targeting a creature not from your current plane. Make a Spirit check; on a success, send them back to their home plane.
  9. Sanctuary Guardian II: Your Sanctuary Guardian becomes a massive creature with a PL of 8. It can remain outside your sanctuary for 1 hour before needing to hibernate.
  10. Ultimate Sanctuary: Create a network of Sanctuaries across different planes. Travel between these Sanctuaries at will. Reduce the cost of tasks for your minions to 1 Inspiration per task. The Sanctuary becomes vast, and creatures can remain in your Sanctuary while you are not there.
Dreamweaver

As a Dreamweaver, you have unlocked the mysteries of dreams and nightmares. You are able to influence the dreamscapes of your allies and enemies, providing relief or inducing fear as needed. This unique power allows you to heal allies and harm foes in ways others cannot comprehend, but sometimes the price of delving into the dreamscape can be unpredictably high.

Dreamweaver's Mark

As an off-action, you can mark a creature within short range. The creature remains marked until you use this ability on a different creature or the marked creature dies. While a creature is marked, you can interact with their dreams and nightmares, and if the creature dies while marked, their soul is trapped in your dream realm. You gain +1 Influence per soul in the Dream Realm.

Influence Spellcaster

Your spells are a grand spectacle, cast through dramatic acts or musical renditions. You cast spells with your Influence Check, and you have spell points equal to your Influence Check.

Nightmare Weapon

As an off-action, spend 1 spell point to create a weapon forged of nightmares that lasts for 1 hour and deals [[1d6]] damage of your choice. You can use your Influence check to wield it. When you create the blade, you can spend an additional spell point to increase the damage by an additional [[1d6]].

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).
  • Gain +1 Spell Point and +1 Class Resource at each of these levels.

Progression Steps

  1. Dream Inducement: As an action, touch a creature that can dream, spend an Inspiration, and make an Influence check. On a success, the creature is stunned until the end of their next turn +1 per success.
  2. Nightmare Weapon II: You can attack twice when you attack as an action using your nightmare weapon. Additionally, your weapon deals an extra +3 damage.
  3. Phantasmal Getaway: As an action, spend 1 Inspiration to conjure a ghostly vehicle that you and your companions can use for a swift escape. The vehicle lasts for 3 hours before fading back into the Dreamsea.
  4. Dreamspace: As an action, spend 1 Inspiration to open a portal or door to a pocket dimension that you dream of and is part of your dream realm. The space lasts for 1 hour, and creatures inside are thrown from the realm at the end.
  5. Phantasmal Aide: As an action, spend 1 Inspiration to create a PL3 servant or minion of your choice. The servant can perform simple tasks, lasts for 1 hour, and is visible only to creatures you choose.
  6. Dream Inducement II: While a creature is stunned by your Dream Inducement, spend an additional Inspiration to cause [[2d6]] water damage or inflict a Cognition condition.
  7. Dreamspace II: As a 10-minute action, spend 1 Inspiration to manifest a dreamy tent or cabin, providing your party a safe and comfortable place to rest for 8 hours. It cannot be used again until after a Long Rest.
  8. Phantasmal Aide II: Your servant becomes a PL6, gains the ability to fly, and lasts for 4 hours before dissipating.
  9. Dreamspace Permanence: Your Dreamspace becomes an infinite realm that is part of the Dreamsea. Anything you can think of exists here. You can close the space from the outside world and creatures that remain here become part of your dream realm. You feed from their souls and eventually they drift into a permanent sleep becoming part of your Dream Realm.
Pactmaker

As a Pactmaker aligned with the dark energies of Ordealis, you've embraced the power lurking within its nine layers, each ordeal shaping your abilities and defining your role as a master of demonic pacts. Your journey through Ordealis has not only granted you unique insights into the realm of demons but also imbued your pacts with the essence of each layer, from the Fields of Desolation to the Temple of Asmodeus.

Make a Deal

As a half-action, give allies within reach range advantage on checks until the end of their next turn, but you have disadvantage on checks until the end of your next turn.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).
  • Gain +1 Class Resource at each of these levels.

Progression Steps

  1. Fields of Desolation Pact: When you Make a Deal, you can invoke the weariness and desolation of the Fields to drain the will of your enemies, giving enemies within your Make a Deal range disadvantage on attack checks.
  2. Iron Dominion Bond: When you Make a Deal, channel the relentless fortitude and cursed iron of the Iron Dominion to forge pacts that give you and your allies +10 armor that lasts for 1 minute.
  3. Clockwork Abyss Accord: When you Make a Deal, utilize the temporal anomalies of the Clockwork Abyss to manipulate the flow of time around your affected allies, granting them an additional off-action on their turn.
  4. Library of Demons Covenant: When you Make a Deal, draw upon the vast knowledge and arcane mysteries within the Library; your allies have advantage on checks for and against spells and magical effects.
  5. Discordant Symphony Harmony: When you Make a Deal, harness the chaotic energies of the Discordant Symphony, dealing [[1d10]] thunder damage to enemy creatures within your Make a Deal range.
  6. Silent Void Pact: When you Make a Deal, your allies gain the invisible condition, invoking the Silent Void's muffling silence to shield them.
  7. River of Souls Bond: When you Make a Deal, you can read the surface thoughts of a creature within your Make a Deal range.
  8. Fields of Torment Accord: When you Make a Deal, bolster the spirits of your allies with the unyielding resolve of those who traverse the Fields of Torment, granting them immunity to Cognitive conditions.
  9. Asmodeus’ Judgment: Your Make a Deal range becomes Short range, an off-action, and you no longer have disadvantage when you use Make a Deal.
  10. Silent Guardian: When you Make a Deal, cloak your allies in the essence of the Infinite Abyss, giving them the intangible condition. Attacks pass through them without causing harm, and they move with ghostly silence, unseen and unheard. However, the Pactmaker becomes blind while channeling this ability. This blindness cannot be removed or prevented.
Shepherd

Shepherds of Souls are itinerant mystics who bridge the realms of the living and the dead. They guide lost spirits to their final rest, ward off malevolent entities, and provide solace to those who mourn. Through rituals and spectral tools, they manipulate the fragile boundary between life and death, balancing mercy and might.

Soul Lantern

A large lantern made with Mournesteel that gives power over souls. Check of your choice, deals [[1d10]] solar damage. Deals an additional [[1d4]] eclipse damage per spell point used before the attack.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).
  • Gain +5 Soul Harvest Capacity at each of these levels.

Progression Steps

  1. Blinding Radiance: Your lantern can emit a blinding flash. As an off-action, impose disadvantage on the next attack of a creature targeting you or an ally within short range.
  2. Spectral Ward: As an action, create a protective aura. Allies within short range gain immunity to Psychic damage and advantage on Spirit checks until the end of your next turn.
  3. Frozen Soul: Add a binding effect to your Soul Lantern. Creatures damaged by your lantern must succeed on a Spirit check or take the frozen condition until the end of your next turn.
  4. Phantom Hunter: Your Soul Lantern gains a ranged attack. As an action, throw a spectral flame from your lantern at a creature within medium range, dealing [[2d6]] fire damage.
  5. Ethereal Chains: As a half-action, launch chains of light from your lantern. A creature within short range must succeed on a Spirit check or be pinned until the end of their next turn.
  6. Spectral Chains: As an off-action, bind a spirit or undead creature within short range. They must succeed on a Spirit check (15) or be restrained until the end of their next turn.
  7. Ethereal Step: Spend 1 spell point, take the intangible condition until the end of your turn. Ending your turn inside an object deals [[1d6]] Psychic damage to you.
  8. Guiding Light: As an action, mark a spirit or undead creature. Allies gain advantage on attacks against the marked target until the end of your next turn.
  9. Banishing Light: Spend 1 spell point to unleash a burst of light from your lantern. All spirits, demons, and undead within short range must make a Spirit check or be banished to their original plane of existence until the end of your next turn.
  10. Warden's Vigil: Once per long rest, summon a spectral guardian for 1 minute. The guardian occupies a space within medium range and provides the following effects:
    • Deals [[2d8]] Psychic damage to enemies within reach at the start of its turn.
    • Allies in short range of the guardian heal for [[1d6]] at the start of their turn.
    • Spirits, demons, and undead in medium range have disadvantage on all checks and saving throws.
Siphon

In the dim twilight of the Eclipse, a realm that whispers of the secrets held between life and death, the Siphons walk a precarious path. These adept practitioners of shadow and light do not merely manipulate the energies of life; they commune with the very essence of existence, drawing upon the Eclipse's enigmatic powers to control the fate of souls. With one hand reaching into the pulsating heart of life and the other ensnared in the cold grip of death, Siphons are the arbiters of a delicate equilibrium, capable of tipping the scales in favor of creation or oblivion.

Soul Harvest

Gain a Soul Harvest Resource, this resource starts at 0 with a maximum capacity of 20. As an action, you can touch a living creature and deal [[1d10]] Eclipse damage. The amount of damage dealt is added to your Soul Harvest, or you can touch an ally and heal them for up to the current amount stored in the Soul Harvest.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).
  • Gain +5 Soul Harvest Capacity at each of these levels.

Progression Steps

  1. Essence Transfer: When you deal damage to an enemy, you can heal an ally within reach range for half the damage dealt.
  2. Shroud of Shadows: As an action spend 1 Inspiration, cloak yourself and one ally in shadows, granting invisibility for 1 minute or until you attack or cast a spell.
  3. Veil of the Reaper: As an action spending 1 Inspiration, become intangible until the end of your next turn.
  4. Necrotic Infusion: Deal an additional [[1d4]] Eclipse damage on weapon attacks.
  5. Grim Harvest: Your Soul Harvest ability becomes a half-action and deals an additional +5 damage.
  6. Spectral Leap: Teleport in a line through the Eclipse a short range, dealing [[1d10]] Eclipse damage to all creatures in that line, filling your Soul Harvest with the damage dealt.
  7. Eternal Sacrifice: Spend your Soul Harvest to increase the check or damage on an attack or the attack of an ally within short range. Every 3 points spent adds +1.
  8. Grim Harvest II: Your Soul Harvest ability can be an off-action and deals an additional +5 damage (10 total).
  9. Death's Embrace: As an action, you can Soul Harvest any number of targets within short range.
  10. Zuinmuir’s Covenant: As an action, become an avatar of death until the end of your next turn. You can choose any creature within medium range to take the death condition. Make a Spirit check with -5 per creature you choose; on a failure, your body is taken by the god of death, Zuinmuir, and you die instead.
Tactician

The Tactician is a master of battlefield strategy, precision strikes, and adaptability. With sharp instincts and an intimate understanding of combat dynamics, they analyze their enemies' weaknesses, exploit vulnerabilities, and provide critical support to allies. Whether leading the charge or operating independently, the Tactician turns the tide of battle with calculated precision and tactical brilliance.

Exploit Weakness

As an off-action spending 1 Inspiration, when you hit with a weapon attack deal +5 additional damage.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).
  • Gain +1 Class Resource at each of these levels.

Progression Steps

  1. Tactical Evasion: Anticipate attacks and reposition to minimize impact; when an attacker you can see hits you, use your reaction to halve the damage.
  2. Adaptive Combatant: Turn everyday objects into weapons; your unarmed strikes and improvised weapons deal [[1d6]] physical damage.
  3. Exploit Weakness II: When you use Exploit Weakness, also impose the Bleeding and Confused conditions on the target.
  4. Battlefield Medic: When you take the Dodge action, heal an adjacent ally for +5.
  5. Coordinated Assault: After successfully hitting an enemy, your next attack against them has advantage.
  6. Elemental Opportunist: Your unarmed strikes or improvised weapons can deal any elemental damage type of your choice.
  7. Precision Overload: Your Exploit Weakness ignores armor and immunity.
  8. Cloaked Medic: When you heal an ally, grant them the invisible condition until the end of their next turn.
  9. Strike and Heal: When you heal an ally, make a free attack against an enemy within reach range.
  10. Calculated Execution: When you make an attack and roll a success+, choose the outcome from the damage table instead of rolling.
Talents

Support Talents crystallize your approach to mending wounds and curing ailments. These traits define your unique healing style, whether it's through divine intervention, herbal remedies, or innovative medical techniques.

Alchemystic

Whether brewing elixirs that heal wounds and fortify spirits, crafting scents that alter moods and perceptions, or rigging arcane devices that protect and devastate, the Alchemystic is a versatile force on the battlefield and beyond. Their knowledge is their weapon, and their ingenuity is their shield. Through their mastery of mystical concoctions, they navigate the complex interplay of light and shadow, substance and spirit, crafting a legacy that echoes through the ages.

Jury-Rigged Protection

Your knack for improvisation extends to creating makeshift barriers and protections. As an action, you can create a barrier that provides temporary armor to those behind it. The barrier can be a wall or half dome that can encompass short range radius and has armor equal to your Intellect check. The barrier resembles the environment it was cast in, and creatures require an Observation check to discern that it is not part of the environment.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Cat's Eye Brew: As an action spending 1 Inspiration, create a potion that grants the drinker night vision and the ability to see through illusions for 1 minute.
  • Alchemical Accelerant: You've developed a potent accelerant that can enhance your speed. By spending 1 Inspiration as an action, you can drink this accelerant and double your movement speed for 1 minute. After the minute, you take the Exhaustion condition for 1 minute.
  • Bargain Brewer: When you craft an elixir, you craft 2. The other is stored in your inventory or can be used with the other, doubling the effect.
  • Black Blood Tonic: As an action spending 1 Inspiration, create a potion that turns the drinker's blood into a lethal poison for any creature that ingests it, dealing 5 toxic damage to melee attackers when they land a successful attack.
  • Hooch of Haste: As an action spending 1 Inspiration, craft this Hooch that gives an additional action on the drinker’s next turn. However, if they drink it again on the next turn, they take the blind condition.
  • Arcane Artillery: (Gain 1 Inspiration) As an action, you can rig a mundane item to serve as an arcane cannon. This contraption can fire a blast of arcane energy, using your Intellect modifier as the attack roll and dealing damage equal to your Inspiration roll [[1d8]] physical Damage to a single target. The cannon lasts for 1 minute and can be fired by anyone as an action.
  • Alchemical Infusion: You've learned to imbue your weapons with alchemical substances for a short time. By spending 1 Inspiration as an action, you can coat your weapon in a substance that adds +2 elemental damage (acid, fire, ice, etc.) to your weapon attacks for 1 minute.
  • Tawny Owl Draught: As an action spending 1 Inspiration, create a potion that enhances the drinker's stamina regeneration, making them immune to the Exhaustion condition for 1 minute but causes blindness after the minute.
  • Arcane Detonator: (Gain 1 Inspiration) As an action spending 1 Inspiration, you can rig a simple object to explode with magical energy. The detonator uses your Inspiration [[1d8]] for damage in a reach range from the device, and the object must be triggered manually or can be set to explode after a certain condition is met (like being moved or time-based).
  • Jack’s Potion: As an action spending 1 Inspiration, create a potion that gives +3 to all checks for 1 minute.
Barber

The Barber, skilled in both the art of grooming and the rudimentary aspects of surgery, is a figure that bridges the gap between daily vanity and the grim realities of life and death. Once common in medieval and early modern societies, they performed a wide array of tasks from cutting hair to amputating limbs. In the Check20 system, the Barber-Surgeon combines these historic roles into a versatile character capable of both healing and harming, reflective of their unique position in society.

Keen Eye for Detail

Years of precise work have honed your observation skills. Gain advantage on Intellect (Medical) checks related to diagnosing ailments, diseases, and curses.

Restorative Trim

As an action, give a minor cosmetic or medical enhancement to give a creature advantage on Influence checks for 1 minute, but you can only use it once per long rest on the same creature.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Scalpel Precision: Your attacks with small blades (daggers, scalpels) deal an additional [[1d4]] damage.
  • Bloodletting: A controversial method that can either harm or heal. As an action, make an Intellect check to either deal damage equal to your Intellect check to an enemy or heal an ally for the same amount. The choice must be made before the check.
  • Anesthetic Brew: You've mastered the creation of pain-relieving concoctions. As a half-action, you can administer an anesthetic to a creature, granting +10 armor for 1 minute, or healing for an equal amount.
  • Master Barber: Your grooming skills can boost morale or disguise. once per long rest as an action, give a creature a makeover, granting them advantage on Influence and Stealth checks for 24 hours.
  • Empathic Listener: Your experience dealing with clients has made you an excellent listener. Gain advantage on an Influence or Intellect check related to understanding or persuading someone.
  • Hygienic Aura (Passive): Your presence and practices promote health, granting allies within medium range +5 total wounds.
  • Regenerist: As a full-day action, you can regenerate or create a new limb if one is missing on a willing creature. After the day of work, you cannot use this feature again for 1 month or until you gather more supplies (should be a fair cost, around 300gp or a rare resource).
  • Disguise Craft: As a 10-minute action with your tools, you can alter a person's appearance significantly. This allows you or an ally to blend into a crowd or impersonate someone else.
  • Network of Whispers: Your profession allows you to hear rumors and secrets. Once per session, you can declare that you've heard a rumor relevant to your current situation with a successful Luck check, subject to Narrator approval.
  • Blade Dancer: You wield your razors and scissors with such precision that they become extensions of your body. +3 Attack Bonus with slashing weapons.
Flapper

The Elemental Flapper is a vivacious force of nature, seamlessly blending charm and charisma with elemental powers that reflect their dazzling personality and volatile spirit. Whether in the urbane settings of high society or the raw wilderness, they manipulate fire, water, air, or earth to enhance their movements, deceive foes, and captivate allies with elemental flair.

Elemental Flourish

Your mastery of elemental charisma allows you to infuse actions with captivating elemental displays. When you succeed on an Influence check, you grant an ally within short range advantage on their next check.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Elemental Grace: once per long rest, reroll a failed check. If the reroll is successful, gain advantage on your next check of the same type.
  • Elemental Strike: As an off-action, channel elemental energy into your unarmed strike. Deal [[1d6]] elemental damage of a chosen type.
  • Reflexive Element: As a reaction, make an Influence check to invoke your elemental energy to avoid harm. On a success, gain advantage on a check to dodge or escape and reduce incoming damage by [[1d6]] per success.
  • Elemental Serenade: As an action, weave elemental energy into a performance. Make an Influence check and on success, all chosen creatures within short range become charmed until the end of your next turn.
  • Elemental Minion: As an action, spend 1 Spell Point and summon a PL3 medium-sized Elemental creature of your design and type. It remains for 1 hour and can complete simple tasks. You can have up to 3 minions at one time.
  • Blending Aura: As a half-action, channel elemental energy to adapt to your surroundings. Gain the invisible condition until the end of your next turn or when you take an aggressive action.
  • Elemental Charisma: As an action, attempt to charm a creature within short range with a dazzling elemental display. Make an Influence check; on success, the target is charmed until the end of your next turn.
  • Elemental Surge: As an action, leap up to medium range. Leave behind a short-range burning path that deals [[1d6]] Fire damage to creatures passing through it. Knock a target prone on a successful strike, dealing [[1d6]] Thunder damage.
  • Elemental Verse: As an action, create an elemental ripple in your voice. Make an Influence check; on success, creatures within short range have disadvantage on their next check.
  • Aetherial Glow: As an action, emit a soft elemental light that creates a calming aura. Allies within short range gain advantage on Spirit checks until the end of your next turn.
Harmonizer

Harmonizers are gifted individuals who draw upon the ancient wisdom of the stars and the subtle energies of celestial bodies to support their allies. With a deep understanding of astrological alignments and cosmic forces, they navigate the battlefield with an otherworldly grace, channeling the universe's vast energies to heal, protect, and empower their companions. Through their connection to the cosmos, they bring about auspicious events, realign energies for optimal outcomes, and provide insights that transcend ordinary understanding.

Attunement

As an action, you can attune a creature within reach range. While attuned, you can react to their needs and give them the Help action as a reaction for 1 minute. You can only attune to one creature at a time.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Stellar Shield: As a reaction when your attuned ally is attacked, conjure a shield of starlight that grants them +5 armor until the end of their next turn.
  • Orbital Assistance: When you give a creature the Help action, their movement does not provoke opportunity attacks until the end of their next turn.
  • Gravity Well: When giving the Help action to an attuned ally, spend 1 Inspiration and create a gravitational field that pulls enemies within a short range towards a point of your choosing within short range of the target. The targeted creature must be large or smaller and can make a Strength or Agility check to deny the movement by half per success.
  • Nebulous Escape: As a reaction when your attuned ally starts their turn, give them the Disengage action as a free action, enveloping them in a cloud of nebula-like mist to obscure their exit.
  • Critical Attunement: When your attuned ally makes a Critical hit, they deal triple the damage instead of double.
  • Attunement II: You can have 2 attuned creatures.
  • Celestial Counsel: As an action, draw upon the wisdom of the stars to offer sage advice. You can conduct a celestial reading to provide guidance on a decision or problem faced by the party, potentially revealing hidden information or suggesting auspicious actions.
  • Astral Projection: As an action, project your consciousness into the astral plane to communicate with celestial beings or explore distant locations. While in this astral state, you are intangible and can only interact with other intangible beings. No creatures can hear you, but they might see you if they have high Spirit.
  • Starlit Path: Your connection to the cosmos guides your journey. When traveling under the night sky, you and your party move more swiftly and are less likely to encounter danger, as if the stars themselves watch over you.
  • Solar Finding: As an action spending Inspiration, cause a celestial light from the sky to a location you desire. This can be used to find lost items, track a creature, blind a creature temporarily, or any number of uses.
Lifeweaver

With hands that can both heal and harm, Lifeweavers are revered for their unique ability to manipulate the very essence of life. Drawing upon the interconnectedness of all beings, they redistribute health, siphon vigor from foes to fortify friends, and bind adversaries in shared fates of suffering. Their presence is a balm to allies and a bane to enemies, embodying the duality of creation and destruction.

Conduit

As an action, touch 2 creatures and transfer up to 10 wounds from one to the other. If a creature is unwilling, you must make a contested Spirit check against them.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Condition Conduit: When you use Conduit, you can choose to transfer conditions instead.
  • Conduit II: When you use Conduit, if a creature is unwilling, you can make a Spirit check, not contested.
  • Enhanced Conduit: When you use Conduit, you may do so at a short range.
  • Mending Miasma: As an action spending 1 Inspiration, create a healing fog within a short range from you that heals allies for +1 at the start of their turn and deals -1 damage to enemies at the start of theirs.
  • Life Link: Choose a creature within reach; whenever you take damage, that creature also takes that damage.
  • Mana Conduit: When you use Conduit, and each creature has spell points, you can choose to transfer up to 5 spell points from one creature to the other.
  • Disease Conduit: When you use Conduit and spend 1 Inspiration, you can choose to transfer a disease in its current state from one creature to another.
  • Curse Conduit: When you use Conduit and spend 1 Inspiration, you can choose to transfer a curse in its current state from one creature to another.
  • Resurgence: When an ally falls to 0 hit points, use your reaction to give a creature the opportunity to make a Spirit check, regaining [[1d10]] wounds on a success.
  • Dual Edict of Inspiration: By spending 2 Inspiration points, simultaneously apply two different effects from the Inspiration mechanic to a single target or one effect to two different targets.
Medic

The Medic is a versatile class that seamlessly blends the healing prowess of a traditional medic with the martial skills of a warrior. They excel at rapidly treating wounds and injuries during combat, ensuring their allies remain in fighting shape. In addition to their potent healing capabilities, Medics are well-trained in combat. They can skillfully wield weapons and armor, holding their own against formidable opponents.

Frontline Resilience

Your constant exposure to battlefield chaos has made you resilient. Gain advantage on checks against fear or intimidation effects.

Last Stand

As an action, spend 1 Inspiration and touch a creature, healing them for +5 and preventing conditions until the end of their next turn.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Fast Healer: You can use Inspiration as an Off-Action.
  • Distant Healing: When you use an Inspiration as an action, you can do so at short range.
  • Dual Healing: When you use an Inspiration as an action, you can target 2 creatures.
  • Iron Will: If you are to take a non-major condition, expend 1 Inspiration and make an Intellect Check. On a success, you prevent the condition.
  • Called Strikes: You can make a called shot at -6 instead of -10.
  • Pushing Attack: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one Inspiration to attempt to drive the target back. If the target is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength check. Push the target up to 20 ft away from you, reducing the distance by 5 ft per success.
  • Wide-Swing Healing: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can expend 1 Inspiration to heal another creature within the same action within 5 ft.
  • Rapid Response: When an ally takes the Injured condition, you can use a free action to move your movement speed towards them and, as an off-action, spend 1 Inspiration to heal them.
  • Battlefield Commander: As a half-action, spend 1 Inspiration to grant an ally within earshot an immediate off-action.
  • Shielded Recovery: While healing an ally, both you and the ally gain +3 armor until your next turn.
Mossheart

Mosshearts are living embodiments of nature's boundless power, blending the resilience of the earth with the regenerative properties of flora and fungi. These guardians of the wild harness the essence of the natural world to protect, heal, and fortify, creating a symbiotic bond between themselves and the life around them. A Mossheart's presence brings a sense of balance and harmony, offering allies not only support but also a connection to the untamed beauty of nature. The Mossheart’s abilities go beyond simple healing or protection; they shape the battlefield into an extension of the natural world. Thorny barriers, regenerative blooms, and animated guardians form an arsenal as versatile as it is effective. They create opportunities to halt enemy advances, protect allies, or even transform the tide of combat through their deep connection to nature.

Verdant Renewal

Expend 1 Inspiration to expel pollen in a short range, healing you and all of your allies for +5 healing or +5 armor.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Nature’s Rebuke: As a reaction to an enemy’s attack, spend 3 spell points to create a thorny backlash. Make a Spellcasting check to reflect half of the damage back at the attacker. For an additional 2 spell points, reflect the entire damage.
  • Nature’s Mana: Gain +5 Spell points. When you cast spells while in nature, recover +1 spell point when you get a success+ on spells you cast.
  • Twice Bloomed: After using Verdant Renewal, any creatures that are healed or armored take half damage on the next attack that hits them.
  • Nature’s Sentinel: Expand 1 Inspiration to summon a PL4 guardian made of moss and branches. The guardian remains for 1 minute and can use your Inspiration in the same manner you can.
  • Hidden Grove: once per long rest, as an action spending an Inspiration, create a small door made of moss and stone that opens into a secret grove. You can remain in this place for 1 day, allowing you to get some downtime and recover. Only creatures you choose can enter this space, and it prevents creatures from spying on you.
  • Verdant Renewal II: Your Verdant Renewal range is increased to medium range.
  • Lash of Thorns: As an action spending 1 Inspiration, summon thorny vines that lash out and bind up to two enemies within short range, dealing 5 nature damage and restricting their movement for one turn.
  • Nature Step: As an action, spend 1 Inspiration. Choose yourself and another creature to step into the shadow of a tree, stone, or other natural structure, teleporting up to medium range to another shadow within sight.
  • Thorned Renewal: When you use Verdant Renewal, it gives each healed or armored creature thorns that deal 5 piercing damage to creatures that hit them with a melee attack.
  • Shapeshift: Spend 1 Inspiration to transform into creatures like a fox, hare, or owl, granting benefits such as enhanced senses, stealth, or flight for up to 1 hour or until dismissed. You cannot cast spells or use Inspiration while in this form.
Puppeteer

The Puppeteer is a master of creativity and strategy, wielding their crafted puppets to dominate the battlefield and shape the narrative of any encounter. These animated constructs are more than tools of war; they are extensions of the Puppeteer’s will, forged from imagination and brought to life through skill and determination. Whether commanding a horde of shadowy marionettes or a single, intricately designed masterpiece, the Puppeteer is a force to be reckoned with. Each puppet offers endless possibilities for customization and utility. From fearsome warriors with elemental-infused strikes to agile scouts capable of navigating terrain others cannot, the Puppeteer adapts their creations to suit the challenges at hand. Their puppets can defend allies, disrupt enemies, or even perform tasks that require precision or ingenuity, acting as both tools and companions in the journey.

Puppet

As an action, spend 1 Inspiration to summon a PL3 puppet of your design within a short range that lasts for 1 hour. Directing your puppet requires no action but maintaining control requires focus; because of this, you can only have 2 puppets active at a time. It has a [[1d4]] weapon of your choice. Your puppets have limited range and can only move up to short range from you.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Combat Refinement: Your puppet gains combat proficiency, giving it a +2 attack bonus and damage. Your puppets also can remain once created until you take a long rest.
  • Aegis Framework: Increase the puppet's durability by reinforcing its structure. It has +1 PL and an additional +5 armor.
  • Swift Ambulator: As your action, enhance the puppet's mobility momentarily, granting it additional movement options such as flying, swimming, or burrowing at a speed equal to your speed until the end of your next turn.
  • Elemental Embodiment: Infuse your puppets with elemental damage (fire, ice, lightning, etc.), allowing them to deal that damage with their weapon attacks for 1 minute.
  • Reactive Adaptation: The puppet can now react to incoming attacks, gaining the ability to use your Off-Action (reaction) to impose disadvantage on attack rolls against it once per round.
  • Sentience Spark: As an action, spending 1 Inspiration, grant a puppet a limited form of sentience, allowing it to perform simple tasks, make basic decisions, have no limited range, and communicate simple concepts to you without direct control for 1 hour.
  • Puppet Master: You can have up to 3 puppets at one time. Your puppets are PL5 and can move up to a medium range from you.
  • Puppeteer's Veil: As an action, your puppets emit a veil of shadows that grant allies within reach range stealth advantage until the end of your next turn.
  • Puppet Reinforcement: Your puppet gains +10 armor and can be equipped with Standard Weapons.
  • Ethereal Strings: As an action, spending 1 Inspiration, one of your puppets can gain the intangible or invisible condition until the end of your next turn.
Merchant

A shrewd and resourceful individual who knows how to make a profit no matter the circumstances. The Merchant is a master of trade and commerce, always looking for new opportunities to expand their business and increase their wealth. They are not content to simply rely on combat and adventuring to earn a living. Instead, they think beyond these traditional means and use their wits and cunning to get ahead. Whether it's looking for valuable items to sell or stealing from a dragon's hoard to further a political campaign, the Merchant of Adventure is always one step ahead.

Class Features

  • Starting Wealth: Start with 500 gp or 2d100 x5, and 4 Merchant Tokens that are powerful and magical representations of your wealth. These tokens can take any shape you wish, such as a coin, tattoo, or ring. You can spend these tokens on different business opportunities to possibly gain more tokens. If you show your token to another merchant or those in power, they will identify you as a Merchant, which could open doors but also mark you as a target. The Merchant Investments section offers samples of how you can spend your merchant tokens.
  • Social Network: In most well-populated areas, you have an ally, contact, or associate who might aid you with business endeavors, information, or finding the best deals. Make a social check of the narrator's choice (Influence, Luck, Spirit, or another based on the city's nature). On a success, you find your contact, who is connected in the town and can provide rumors, tips, and leads on whatever you might need. On a failure, you have an enemy in the area and should be on guard.
  • Appraisal: Quickly assess item values, identify if they're magical (but not if they're cursed), and find items for sale at a 10-30% discount when shopping, based on a successful Luck or Observation check.

Equipment

  • Armor: Choose one:
    • Light Armor (6 armor; Stealth +1, Agility +1)
    • Medium Armor (10 armor; Movement -10, Stealth -2, Magic -2, Agility +1)
  • Weapon: Choose one:
    • Standard Weapon (Agi or Str; 1 hand, Light; [[1d6]] Physical)
    • Revolver (Agi; medium range, 1 hand; [[2d6!]] Piercing)
    • Siege Crossbow (Str; 2 hand, Hefty, Medium Range, Mechanical, Reload; [[2d6]] Piercing)
Paths

The Merchant's path is an entrepreneurial venture of commerce and craft. Progressing through the levels enhances your skills in negotiation, trade, and craftsmanship, evolving from a local trader to a renowned merchant prince.

Bio-Brewer

The Bio-Brewer delves into the mysteries of life and mutation, using alchemical concoctions to reshape the bodies of allies, enemies, and even themselves. They walk the line between genius and monstrosity, balancing utility, raw power, and the unpredictable nature of mutation.

Mutagen

Administer a Mutagen to an ally as an action within reach range. The drinker gains a temporary mutation for 1 minute of your choice. At the end of the minute, the target must make a Survival check:

  • Quills: Spines spawn from the target, melee attackers take 3 piercing damage.
  • Gills: Gain the ability to breathe underwater and swim at normal speed.
  • Enhanced Reflexes: Gain Advantage on Agility and Strength Checks.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).
  • Gain +1 Spell Point at each of these levels.

Progression Steps

  1. Alchemical Adaptation: You’ve mastered the basics of mutagen crafting. Mutagens can now be administered as half-action.
  2. Mutagen: Feral Tonic: Gain claws that deal [[1d6]] Slashing damage for 1 minute.
  3. Alchemical Consultant: Your knowledge of mutations and alchemy makes you a sought-after expert. Gain Advantage on Influence Checks when offering advice, diagnosing ailments, or negotiating services related to alchemy or biology.
  4. Cosmetic Alchemy: Craft cosmetic mutations, such as glowing hair, shimmering skin, or translucent skin. These changes are purely aesthetic and last until undone.
  5. Toxic Infusion: You can add a toxic element to your mutagens. Creatures mutated by your brews deal [[1d6]] Toxic damage on melee attacks for the duration.
  6. Chitinous Mutagen: Creatures under your mutagen gain +10 Armor when they are afflicted with the mutagen.
  7. Adaptive Reflexes: You refine mutagens to enhance reflexes. Creatures with your mutagen effects gain Advantage on Agility Checks.
  8. Regenerative Brew: Mutagens can now provide minor healing. Once per combat, a creature drinking your mutagen regains [[1d8]] health.
  9. Mutagen: Hive Mind: A creature with your mutagen can use telepathic communication with all other mutagen-affected creatures within medium range.
  10. Predatory Mutation: A creature with your mutagen has +[[1d6]] to attack checks.
  11. Deadly Mutation: A creature with your mutagen has +[[1d6]] to melee damage.
  12. Spectral Transformation: Your mutagens now affect incorporeal creatures. Creatures under mutagen effects can strike intangible enemies.
  13. Alchemical Emporium: Once per month, as a 1-hour action, you can establish an Alchemical Emporium that lasts for 24 hours. The Emporium attracts NPCs to browse your wares, request commissions, or offer trades. You can sell your crafted items at 150% of their base value and accept one unique custom request during this time, earning gold, rare materials, or influence points with local factions. For the duration, the Emporium grants allies within 30 feet Advantage on social checks, and enemies must succeed on a Spirit Check to approach aggressively. When the Emporium closes, roll a Luck Check to determine if its reputation spreads favorably or attracts the attention of rivals.
Gambler

You’re a gambler at heart, driven by the thrill of high stakes and the promise of wealth. Money flows through your hands like water, and you’re often chasing the next big score. Ready to stake it all on a single throw if that’s what it takes. For you, gold isn’t just currency; it’s a source of power, a catalyst for your spells, and a wellspring of vitality that few can understand. Each time you win big, you feel reinvigorated, as though luck itself has blessed you with a burst of arcane energy.

GP Spellcaster

You use the powerful GP to create spells. As an action spend GP to gain spell points with a maximum equal to your Luck check, the points remain for 1 minute or until cast. You spend 10gp to make 1 spell point.

High Roller

When making a Luck check in a gambling situation, you can reroll the check and must take the new result. Additionally, when winning a bet or gamble, you gain a temporary boost of confidence, granting you a spell point.

Spell Spender

As an action, you can create fake GP using a spell point. When you use a spell point to create GP you create [[1d100]] gold that lasts for [[2d4]] days. It holds up to all inspection, magical or otherwise until the end of the duration when it turns to rot. This GP cannot be used to create spell points.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).
  • Gain +1 Spell Point at each of these levels.

Progression Steps

  1. Gamble Your Life: As an action, you can make a high stakes bet with a willing creature. You both roll a 1d100, and the loser takes damage equal to the difference between the rolls. This damage can't be reduced or prevented in any way.
  2. Double-Down Gamble: As an action, challenge an enemy to a game of chance. You both make contested Luck checks. The loser takes [[4d6]] Psychic damage.
  3. Deceptive Gamble: As a reaction when targeted by an attack, make a Stealth check contested by the attacker's Observation check. If you win, you deceive the creature and the attack swings wildly. If the attack is with a weapon and it fails, the creature is disarmed.
  4. Extradimensional Gamble: once per long rest, as an action, you can propose a bet to a creature you can see. If it accepts, you both make a Spirit check. Whoever fails is sent to a vacation home where they spend the next minute relaxing.
  5. Gambling Charm: Use your action to make an Influence check against a creature's Observation. If you win, the creature is charmed by you for 1 minute or until you or your companions do something harmful to it.
  6. High-Stakes Gamble: Propose a bet to a creature within short range. Both make contested Survival checks. The loser becomes stunned until the end of their next turn.
  7. Gamble Your Soul: As an action, challenge a creature with the gods as overseers. Each of you roll a 1d6. The winner rolls on the Win Table while the loser rolls on the Loss Table.
  8. Chronus' Favor: Winning a gamble grants you a glimpse into the future, giving you advantage on all checks for the rest of the day. Losing, however, muddles your Observation of time, and you suffer disadvantage on checks for the same duration.
  9. Celestial Luck: You have Luck points equal to your Luck check. You can use a Luck point to reroll a check as a reaction.
  10. Divine Gambit: On a winning gamble, you gain a +2 to a check of your choice. Losing a gamble results in a -2 to a check of the Narrator’s choice.

Win Table (Roll 1d6)

  1. Brakkus' Might: Your next melee attack gains a +10 bonus to attack and damage.
  2. Chronus' Temporal Shift: You have 3 actions on your next turn.
  3. Dumda's Harmony: Heal all allies within short range for [[4d6]].
  4. Exembar's Order: Instantly rearrange the battlefield, moving any creature within short range to a different spot.
  5. Jesha's Revelation: Know the location of one person or object of your choice, as long as it is on the same plane of existence; you're also immune to illusions for 1 minute.
  6. Zuinmuir's Protection: One creature of your choice is immune to all damage until the end of their next turn.

Loss Table (Roll 1d6)

  1. Brakkus' Weakness: You are unable to take reactions until the end of your next turn.
  2. Chronus' Halt: You cannot move during your next turn.
  3. Dumda's Silence: You cannot speak until the end of your next turn, preventing any verbal spell casting.
  4. Exembar's Imbalance: You have disadvantage on all checks until the end of your next turn.
  5. Jesha's Blindness: You are blind until the end of your next turn.
  6. Zuinmuir's Burden: Instantly lose half of your current wounds; if you are below half, take 1 injury.
Incantatore

In the shadows of grandeur and the limelight of intrigue, you've navigated the treacherous waters of ambition and desire. Known to many as the Incantatore, your journey has been one of cunning and allure, a path carved by the sheer force of your presence and the magnetic charm you wield like a blade. Yet, beneath the surface of calculated smiles and strategic flirtations lies a soul weary of the facade, a spirit yearning for authenticity beyond the roles you've played.
