Your expertise in the art of seduction has always been your weapon and your shield, guiding you through the complexities of human desires, twisting intentions to your will with a mere glance or whisper.

Influence Spellcaster

Your magic is as enticing as your charm, using allure to cast spells that beguile the senses. You cast spells with your Influence Check, and you have spell points equal to your Influence Check.

Enthrall

As an action, spend 1 spell point to cast a silent charm on a creature within short range, requiring a successful Spellcasting check. While charmed, your Influence checks against the creature automatically succeed, and they are willing to assist you and your party, provided it does not harm them, others, or involve violence. You may extend the charm's duration to 1 hour by spending 3 spell points, increasing the duration by an additional hour for each spell point spent after that.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).
  • Gain +1 Spell Point at each of these levels.

Progression Steps

  1. Bewitching Performance: Perfect the art of bewitching those around you with a single dance, song, or act. As an action, make an Influence Check on a target within short range. On a success, they take the charmed condition with you as the source until the end of your next turn.
  2. Kiss of Despair: Your kisses are known to lead creatures to despair. As an action, make a kiss attack on a humanoid creature using Influence as the check. On a success, deal [[1d6]] psychic damage.
  3. Caress of Ruin: Your touch can be both pleasurable and painful. As a half-action, touch a creature charmed by you. The creature takes [[1d6]] psychic damage.
  4. Heartbreaker: You're adept at exploiting the emotional vulnerability of others. Gain advantage on Influence checks when dealing with individuals who are emotionally compromised.
  5. Echoing Tales: Your stories are so captivating that they linger in listeners' minds. When you make a spell attack and the roll lands on a 5, the story reverberates, casting the spell again without cost.
  6. Unseen Weaver: Your spellcasting is as elusive as the stories you tell. Your magic is unseen, its presence known only by its effects, allowing for subtle manipulations and strategic advantages.
  7. Flirtatious Flair: Inspire others through stirring words or music. As an action, choose a creature within short range. They gain [[1d6]] to their next check or half as much to their damage.
  8. Bewitching Command: Issue simple commands to a creature you have charmed. As a half-action, command a creature charmed by you within short range to immediately perform an action. After the action, the creature is no longer charmed and has advantage to resist your charms in the future.
  9. Irresistible Presence: Your allure captivates all around you. As an action, humanoid creatures within short range must make an Observation check or become charmed by you for 1 minute.
  10. Queen of Hearts: In times of dire need, channel your full seductive powers to become the ultimate temptress. When you activate this feature as an action, for 1 hour, your Influence Checks become 20 without rolling. When you seduce a creature using these checks, they become charmed by you for the hour, gaining +20 loyalty and a willingness to throw their lives down for you. However, at the end of the hour, you age by [[1d6]] x 3 years, and your beauty begins to fade.
Nightshade

Masters of fear and toxic beauty, the Nightshade blends deadly flora and subconscious manipulation into a powerful toolkit. With their mastery of Spirit and alchemical craft, they weave fearsome illusions and deadly toxins, crafting items and artifacts that carry their lethal artistry. These merchants of terror understand both the psychology of dread and the tangible allure of the items they sell.

Spirit Spellcaster

Your magic is infused with the supernatural. You cast spells with your Spirit Check and have spell points equal to half your Spirit Check.

Deadly Bloom

As an action, summon a spectral flower that deals [[1d10]] Toxic damage and imposes the Fear condition on creatures within short range on a failed Survival Check. The flower lingers in the area for up to 1 minute.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).

Progression Steps

  1. Fearmonger’s Market: You specialize in crafting and selling items that inspire awe and dread and can be sold for 5gp each. Use 1 hour of downtime to create:
    • Phantom Petals: Grants Disadvantage on checks when ingested. Can be applied to a weapon as a half-action.
    • Nightshade Bombs: A throwable flower that imposes Blind within reach.
    • Fearful Fragrances: As an action, spray the fragrance. A creature within reach range must make a Survival check or take the Fear condition. They gain immunity to this fragrance on a success.
  2. Aura of Dread: Your mere presence inspires unease. As an action, enemies within short range must make a Spirit check or take the Fear condition.
  3. Harvest of Fear: When a creature under the effect of your Fear condition dies, you can harvest its essence as a Nightmare Nectar during downtime. This nectar restores [[1d8]] health to an ally and provides crafting bonuses when sold or used.
  4. Lurking Shadows: You and your allies gain Advantage on Stealth checks in areas affected by your Deadly Bloom.
  5. Toxic Mind: When a creature fails a check against your fear-based abilities, you learn its greatest fear. You have Advantage on future checks against it for 1 minute.
  6. Deadly Bloom Garden: When you use Deadly Bloom, you can summon up to 3 flowers within medium range.
  7. Nightshade Grasp: As an action spending 1 spell point, make a Spellcasting check targeting a creature within short range. On a success, they take the Pinned condition until the end of their next turn and [[1d6]] piercing damage. Increase the number of targets for every additional spell point spent.
  8. Deadly Bloom Spawn: As an action spending 1 spell point, create a deadly bloom spawn, a flower monster of your design, that is a PL4. Its attacks are your Deadly Bloom and can follow simple commands. It remains for 1 minute. You can only have 1 Deadly Bloom Spawn at a time.
  9. Deadly Bloom Teleport: As an action, you can teleport to any of your active Deadly Blooms within long range.
  10. Fearmonger’s Market II: Refine your craft into an art form, creating items that inspire awe and fear. Spend 3 spell points to double the potency of crafted items (e.g., damage, radius, or duration). You gain recognition for your infamous creations.
  11. Haunting Charcoal: A black powder that, when ignited, creates a choking fog that deals [[4d4!]] Toxic damage in a reach range and imposes the Coughing condition.
  12. Terror Seeds: As an action, plant the seed in any soft surface. The seed activates when stepped on, releasing a fear-inducing spike. Creatures must succeed on a Spirit Check or take the Fear condition. While feared in this way, all creatures have advantage on attack checks against this creature.
  13. Wither Draught: A consumable elixir that deals [[6d6!]] Psychic damage to the drinker.
Power Player

The Power Player is a master manipulator and strategist, operating from the shadows or stepping into the spotlight to shape the world around them. With an extensive network of government agents, criminal operatives, and influential figures, you pull strings that others can barely see, let alone touch. Your connections open doors to opportunities, resources, and information that can turn the tide of any situation. Your influence extends far beyond the battlefield. Whether negotiating a delicate truce between warring factions, orchestrating the downfall of a rival organization, or securing high-value resources, you leverage your network to weave intricate plots and achieve your goals. Every conversation, deal, and favor becomes a piece of your larger strategy, building a web of alliances and obligations that stretches across the world.

Insider Connections

Once per week or month during downtime, you can call on your network for assistance. Roll a d6 to determine the outcome. Higher rolls yield better results:

  • 1. Betrayed: Your connection has turned against you, selling you out to a rival organization. Expect retaliation or trouble in the near future.
  • 2. Double-Crossed: A rival within the organization takes advantage of your request to undermine your influence. You may face increased challenges or obstacles in your current endeavors.
  • 3. Minor Favor: Your connection provides you with a small favor or piece of information, such as a safehouse location or a tip on a potential business opportunity.
  • 4. Valuable Information: Your connection reveals important information about a rival organization, a hidden treasure, or a secret entrance to a heavily guarded location.
  • 5. Major Favor: Your connection pulls some strings to get you out of a tight spot, such as bribing an official to drop charges or arranging for a valuable resource to be delivered to you.
  • 6. Powerful Boon: Your connection goes above and beyond, providing a significant advantage, such as securing a powerful ally, obtaining a rare and valuable item, or granting influence over a key figure in the organization.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).

Progression Steps

  1. Influencer: You start with a Loyalty tier of Neutral (Tier 1) with one chosen organization or influential individual. These can be within government or criminal circles.
  2. Leverage Loyalty: As an action, spend 2 Loyalty points with a group or individual to gain advantage on any Charisma check you make to interact with them for the next 10 minutes.
  3. Networker: If you successfully aid someone in a significant way (such as saving them from danger or solving a major problem for them), gain 2 Loyalty points with that individual or group.
  4. Favors Owed: As an action, request a favor from someone. The scale of the favor corresponds directly with your Loyalty tier: Tier 2 for a minor favor, Tier 3 for a moderate favor, and Tier 4 or 5 for a major favor.
  5. Friend in High Places: Whenever you level up, gain 1 Loyalty point with a high-ranking individual or group in the city. This represents you maintaining and strengthening your connections.
  6. Charismatic Leader: Once per long rest, give an inspiring speech. Roll a Charisma (Persuasion) check. For every increment of 10 you roll, gain 1 Loyalty point with the audience.
  7. Power Broker: Once per long rest, attempt to broker a significant deal, alliance, or negotiation between organizations. This requires you to make a Loyalty check with each involved party. The success of the deal will depend on the results of these checks.
  8. Puppet Master: Once per long rest, convince an individual to perform a specific action. This requires a Loyalty check with the target. The action cannot be obviously harmful to them.
  9. Chessmaster: Once per long rest, make a Loyalty check with an individual or organization to gain critical information about their plans, vulnerabilities, or strengths.
  10. Kingmaker: Once per in-game year, spend a significant amount of Loyalty points (equal to moving from one tier to the next) to attempt to change the leadership of an organization, start a revolution, or exert significant control over a major event. This ability is intended for major plot developments and should be used with the Narrator's guidance.
Sovereign

Legends are whispered about you in hushed tones, and tales of your exploits circulate through every corner of the realm. Your reputation has grown into a powerful yet perilous asset, turning you into a figure of both awe and unease. While your renown opens doors to alliances and favors, it also draws the watchful eyes of foes, rivals, and those who envy or resent your fame.

Demanding Presence

As an action once per long rest, command all creatures within medium range to focus on you and make an Influence check. On a success, the crowd takes the Charmed condition until the end of your next turn.

Shadowmeld

As an action, gain the Invisible condition while in a crowd or in darkness until the end of your next turn.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).

Progression Steps

  1. Ironmonger Associate: You've developed ties with a respected blacksmith and armorer, providing you with access to quality weaponry and armor. You receive favorable prices and might get the opportunity to invest in or acquire rare items.
  2. Medic's Aid: You've gained the trust of a respected medical practitioner, such as a doctor or nurse. They give you preferential treatment and may occasionally request your help with certain "procurements".
  3. Mystical Mentor: You've caught the eye of an esoteric figure versed in the arcane. They provide you with knowledge and magical items at a more approachable rate and might have special tasks for you.
  4. Speak-easy Owner's Confidence: You're in good with the owner of a local speak-easy. This gives you an advantage when needing information, rooms, or the best moonshine in town. They might also give you special opportunities.
  5. Loyal Following: Your reputation draws loyal followers who aid your business. Gain a small group of followers who can help with business tasks and can also act as bodyguards, messengers, or spies.
  6. Power Broker: You are able to leverage your wealth and influence to make major changes in the local area, such as influencing laws, starting or stopping wars, or controlling the local economy. However, this draws a lot of attention and can make you a target.
  7. Faith's Shepherd: A religious figure of significance, such as a high priest or prophet, is ready to intervene on your behalf. However, such divine intervention might bring scrutiny from religious or anti-religious groups, resulting in potential backlash.
  8. The Ancient One: An ancient and powerful being, such as a vampire lord or elder dragon, owes you a favor. However, calling upon this favor might draw unwanted attention or put you in their debt.
  9. Reputation Manager: Manipulate public opinion to improve your standing, harm a rival, or promote an ally. If your manipulation is discovered, it could backfire.
  10. Ghost Trader: You can completely alter your identity and establish a new one, allowing you to escape from debts, enemies, and obligations. However, you lose all of your previous contacts and must start building your network and reputation from scratch.
Steel Monger

The Steel Monger is an innovative and resourceful master of metallurgy, machinery, and vehicular engineering. A living testament to the industrial prowess of the era, they utilize their unique skill set to create, repair, and modify anything from personal weapons to massive war machines. Whether in the heart of a bustling city or the wilds of an untamed wilderness, their expertise provides tactical advantages, defensive fortifications, and considerable firepower, ensuring their allies are always well-protected and formidable in the face of any challenge.

Battlefield Armorer

As a half-action, you can repair or reinforce an ally's armor, giving a creature [[2d6]] Armor. Armor points above the armor’s maximum last for 1 hour.

Battlefield Weaponeer

As a half-action, imbue a weapon with power, giving it +2 Attack bonus and +2 Damage for 1 minute. You cannot use this on the same weapon more than once.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).

Progression Steps

  1. Steel Beginnings: As an action using a Crafting check, create a useful item for the current situation like a lockpicking wrench, grappling hook launcher, or alarm clock crab. These items don't need specific descriptions and can do minor things like deal 1d4 damage, unlock a mundane door, or cause a condition until the end of the target's next turn.
  2. Clockwork Companion: You've crafted a loyal, clockwork pet. This automaton can perform basic tasks, assist in combat, and even explode on command. This clockwork creation has a PL3 and can act as independently as you create it to be.
  3. Weaponsmith: Spend one minute at a workbench to improve a weapon, giving it +2 damage. This can only be done to one weapon once without a check, twice with a check, then lastly with a disadvantage check. If any of these checks fail, you cannot attempt it again.
  4. Defensive Engineer: Spend one minute at a workbench to improve armor, either giving it +3 armor or removing up to -3 from a penalty. This can only be done to one piece of armor once without a check, twice with a check, then lastly with a disadvantage check. If any of these checks fail, you cannot attempt it again.
  5. Automata Craftsmen: You've mastered the art of creating automata. As an action, create a PL2 Automaton of your design. You can have a number equal to your Crafting check. These automata have a [[1d4]] basic attack and can be given spare weaponry.
  6. Engineer Suit: Spend 1 Merchant Token and 1 hour at a workbench to create your Engineer’s suit, which has 30 Armor and no penalties.
  7. Vehicle Engineer: Unlock the ability to design and construct vehicles, enhancing your mobility and tactical options. By investing time and Merchant Tokens, craft:
    • Light Vehicle (1 Merchant Token, 3 days): Transports 1-2 passengers; fast and agile; limited storage.
    • Medium Vehicle (2 Merchant Tokens, 7 days): Transports up to 6 passengers; moderate speed and durability; ample storage for goods and equipment.
    • Heavy Vehicle (3 Merchant Tokens, 14 days): Transports 12 passengers; enhanced armor and defenses; equipped with weaponry and living quarters.
  8. Armor Piercing Rifle: Spend 1 Merchant Token to create an armor-piercing rifle.
    Check(Agi, Lck, Str, Obs), long range, 2 hand, close range disadvantage. 3d12! Piercing damage.
  9. War Automata: Master the creation of advanced constructs. Spend 4 Merchant Tokens as an action to create a War Automaton with PL9, an Armor Piercing Rifle, a Great Weapon, and an additional 20 armor. The War Automaton is large enough to house 3 medium-sized creatures.
  10. Ultimate Investment: Establish a manufacturing empire, ensuring a steady flow of income and providing resources for greater projects. Gain:
    • 1d100x10 gp per month.
    • 1d10 Merchant Tokens per month.
Undertaker

The Undertaker is a master of tragic relics and supernatural connections, trading not only in goods but also in memories, spirits, and stories that linger beyond the grave. Their abilities allow them to profit from their unique connection to the afterlife, assisting others in achieving closure or using spectral influence to gather secrets and sway the living.

Whispered Relicst

You can invoke the voices of the dead through a Spirit Relic. As an action, channel a spirit into an item, causing it to speak and reveal knowledge or insight. This ability can unearth a secret, reveal hidden memories, or serve as a medium for messages from beyond the veil. When thrown as a weapon, it deals [[1d4]] Impact damage and an additional [[1d4]] Eclipse damage. You can have a number of Spirit Items equal to your Spirit check.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9:

  • Gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks (no check can exceed 15).

Progression Steps

  1. Guardian Séance: As a half-action, summon a spirit that reduces damage dealt from enemies by -2 for creatures you choose within short range until the end of your next turn.
  2. Spirit-Bound Bargain: You can bind spirits into contracts, leveraging their otherworldly influence to instill dread. As an action, you can attempt to bind a spirit and send it to haunt a target within short range. Make a Spirit check; on a success, the target is afflicted with the Fear condition. On a failure, you experience a brief backlash, causing you to take the Fear condition.
  3. Gravekeeper’s Dirt: As an action, perform a funeral rite on the ground at your feet. Creatures within short range that you choose must make a Spirit check or take [[1d6]] Eclipse damage.
  4. Profane Mark: Place a Profane Mark on a creature as a half-action. They can either use it to gain advantage on a check or deal an additional [[1d4]] Eclipse damage. Once used, the mark dissipates in a subtle puff of ghostly smoke.
  5. Whispered Relicst II: Your spirit relics can now be sold at a value of [[1d100+50]] and deal double damage when thrown.
  6. Whispered Relicst III: Channel the spirit’s emotions into the item. Thrown relics now cause the Fear condition.
  7. Guardian Séance II: When you activate Guardian Séance, the targets you choose also gain +10 Armor until the end of their next turn and have advantage on their next check.
  8. Gravekeeper’s Dirt II: When you activate Gravekeeper’s Dirt, any creatures you choose automatically take the damage and take the Frozen condition for 1 minute.
  9. Soul Broker: Once per month, as an action spending 1 Merchant Token, summon the spirit of a notable deceased figure for a single interaction. The spirit may offer powerful knowledge, perform a service, or enchant an item.
  10. Soul Bazaar: Spend 1 Merchant Token to summon a spectral marketplace where spirits from the afterlife gather to trade and share secrets. The bazaar lasts for 1 minute and appears within medium range around you, filled with eerie booths, ethereal goods, and the haunting murmur of ghostly vendors.
    • Fear Aura: Enemies within the bazaar must make a Spirit check each round or take the Fear condition until they exit the area. Each enemy who fails this check also suffers [[1d6]] Psychic damage.
    • Spectral Wares: Allies within the bazaar can receive a one-time spectral boon from a vendor, such as:
      • Shadow Charm: Deal an additional +2 Eclipse damage on attacks.
      • Phantom Cloak: Gain +1 Agility.
      • Mental Strength: Become immune to the Fear condition.
    • Afterlife Currency: Allies may “purchase” a single-use benefit from the spirits. Once purchased, they cannot receive another benefit.
Talents

Merchant Talents encapsulate your business acumen and craftsmanship. They represent your special flair for trade, be it a keen eye for valuable goods, a talent for persuasive bargaining, or an innovative approach to crafting and selling

Chef

In a world where might often prevails, you've honed an art that captivates both heart and palate. Your culinary prowess transcends mere sustenance, turning every dish into an experience. With a knife as your wand and ingredients as your spells, you weave magic on plates, eliciting joy, nostalgia, or even healing with every bite. As a Culinary Maestro, you not only feed bodies but also souls, creating moments that linger long after the last morsel is savored.

Features

  • Secret Spices: You have a resource of 6 Secret Spice that you can use in a myriad of different ways. You recover these points by spending around $10 at a market or foraging for [[1d6]] hours in the wild.
  • Healing Soup As an action spending 1 Secret Spice Point, you make a healing soup that can heal an ally for 5 wounds or remove 1 corpus condition when they drink it as an action. Each soup is a blend of hearty ingredients like robust potatoes, tender noodles, savory meats, or a signature dish of your region.
  • Spicy Surprise As an action spending 1 Secret Spice Point, you can coat a weapon or ammunition in spice, changing the damage type and dealing an additional 5 physical damage on the next attack.
  • Gourmet Delight Set up a shop as an action that remains for 1 hour, such as a charming booth, roving cart, or cozy nook. Your cooking attracts patrons, earning [[1d20]] gp per Secret Spice Point, and might attract curious wanderers or even hostile creatures intrigued by the tantalizing aromas.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Bountiful Banquet: Spend an hour and 1 Secret Spice Point to prepare a grand feast for up to 6 people. Those who partake gain +3 armor, advantage on checks to save against poison and disease, as well as checks against spells for the next 24 hours. These effects cannot be stacked.
  • Smokescreen Sauté: As an action, toss a mixture of aromatic ingredients into a hot pan, creating a 20ft radius cloud. Creatures in this cloud have the blind and coughing conditions. Spend 1 extra Secret Spice Point per person to protect allies from these conditions. The cloud lasts for 1 minute or until a strong breeze blows it away.
  • Gourmet Guardian: As an action spending 1 Secret Spice Point, conjure a small creature made of food. This creature has 1 hit point and can make melee attacks dealing 1 point of physical damage. The creature follows your commands for 1 minute or until destroyed.
  • Iron Stomach: You gain immunity to toxic damage. Additionally, you can identify potions and poisons by tasting them, without risking harmful effects.
  • Mutagenic Dish: Spend 1 Secret Spice Point to create a dish that temporarily grants the eater a random physical mutation (e.g., increased strength, size, speed, or a new physical feature) for 1 hour. These effects cannot be stacked.
  • Economical Chef: Your dishes cost 1 less Secret Spice Point to prepare.
  • Elemental Meal: Spend 3 Secret Spice Points to create a dish that grants the consumer an elemental ability from the elemental table for 1 minute.
  • Dish of the Planes: Spend 1 Merchant Token to create a dish that transports the consumer to a different plane of existence after consumption.
  • Power Word Spice: Spend 1 Merchant Token to create a spice blend that allows the consumer to cast "Power Word Spice," giving a creature the death condition for 1 minute as they explode into spices. After 1 minute, the creature reconstitutes in a similar unoccupied location with full wounds, injuries, and resources restored.
Caravan Leader

Caravan Leaders are the grand strategists of commerce, who understand that every journey is a venture fraught with both risk and opportunity. With a blend of keen business sense and logistical acumen, they orchestrate the movement of goods across treacherous landscapes, turning each successful delivery into profit. They are adept negotiators, capable organizers, and have a deep understanding of the intricate dance between supply and demand. Their leadership ensures the prosperity of their ventures through both peaceful trade and, when necessary, the strategic use of force to protect their interests.

Caravan Convoy

Utilizing a Merchant Token, Caravan Leaders can organize a convoy of traders and mercenaries to transport goods across the land. These caravans are equipped to handle various threats and are manned by loyal guards who defend the cargo with their lives. The strength and number of the convoy's guards are reflected by the Leader's ability to negotiate and manage resources effectively. You can send out a caravan between two established points, this journey takes a calculated amount of time based on distance. The success is dependent on your Intellect check. After the trip is completed, gain a Merchant Token per success.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Trade Route Tycoon: Establish and secure profitable trade routes. When you establish a trade route between two distant cities, gain a Merchant Token per month that it is in service.
  • Defensive Bargain: While with their caravans, Caravan Leaders can bolster the defenses of their caravan. As an action, give creatures within short range of your caravan +10 armor.
  • Economic Raider: Before embarking on a trade mission, invest in intelligence and defensive measures, ensuring the safety of your cargo and the route's profitability, even in the face of potential threats. This requires spending GP or Merchant Tokens.
  • Merchant Scout: Upon arriving in new territories, assess the economic landscape, identifying opportunities for trade, investment, and expansion. This ensures continued growth and success in new markets.
  • Crisis Management: In times of crisis, rally your caravan. Use a Merchant Token to either reorganize for defense or push through perilous conditions, ensuring the safety of your cargo and crew.
  • Resourceful Recovery: After an encounter, quickly replenish supplies and repair damages. As a 10-minute action, restore the armor of chosen creatures to at least half their maximum.
  • Fortified Caravan: Spend a Merchant Token on your caravan to increase the PL of your guards and fortify your caravan's defenses.
  • Magical Protections: Invest a Merchant Token in magical wards or hire spellcasters to protect the convoy. These protections can neutralize specific threats, such as dispelling natural storms or deterring magical beasts.
  • Economic Espionage: Train or hire spies to undermine competitors or negotiate better terms at destinations. Success can lead to additional Merchant Tokens upon journey completion, capitalizing on weakened competition or favorable markets.
  • Rapid Deployment Caravan: Enhance the speed and efficiency of caravan setup and deployment, reducing journey duration by 25%. This allows for more frequent ventures and faster capitalization on economic opportunities.
Showman

Radiating charisma and charm, the Gregarious Showman is an unforgettable figure. They not only excel in the art of commerce but also stand as a shining beacon of entertainment, amassing a cavalcade of allies and friends. Their irresistible charm and engaging performances captivate hearts, forging bonds that transcend mere business. As masters of ceremonies, their events and galas are the talk of towns and cities. They are at the center of every circle, knowing just how to navigate the social and economic dynamics of each gathering. Equipped with a sharp business acumen and an enchanting personality, the Gregarious Showman turns each transaction into a spectacle, each negotiation into an event, and each market into a stage. With every town they enter, their network expands, their reputation soars, and their influence deepens. A Gregarious Showman is not just a merchant, they are a symbol of unity, celebration, and camaraderie.

Stage of Commerce

As a Gregarious Showman, your business is not merely transactional – it's theatrical. By spending a Merchant Token, you create an extravagant pop-up bazaar just outside town, complete with all the glamor and spectacle one would expect from your reputation. This not only serves as a platform for your business but also provides you with strategic advantages. Depending on your needs, you can choose one of the following options:

  • Spectacle of Servants: You command a cadre of spectral servants to aid you and your allies. These servants can perform simple tasks, such as cleaning, cooking, carrying items, or running errands in the town. They can also serve as a distraction in a pinch, drawing the attention of enemies during a conflict. These servants last for 8 hours. You regain the coin at the end of the 8 hours if you use this effect less than once per week.
  • Fortified Market: Your pop-up bazaar is not just a place of commerce and entertainment; it's also a defensible outpost. Through clever design and the use of illusory magic, it can serve as a secure base of operations, complete with hidden rooms, traps for unwelcome guests, and vantage points for surveillance. The fortress lasts for 8 hours. You regain the coin at the end of the 8 hours if you use this effect less than once per week.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Charismatic Influence: (Gain 1 Merchant Token) Your irresistible charm helps you make fast friends and sway opinions. Spend a Merchant Token to turn a non-hostile NPC into a deeply loyal friend. They gain +30 loyalty, permanent charm condition with you as the source, and a compulsion to aid you in your endeavors.
  • Festive Diplomacy: (Gain 1 Merchant Token) Your events are not just for entertainment – they are also a platform for diplomacy. Spend a Merchant Token to turn a simple gathering into a diplomatic summit, inviting representatives from different factions or groups to broker peace, negotiate deals, or forge alliances.
  • Final Act: As a reaction, when you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, make an Influence Check. On a success, drop to 1 hit point instead. On a success+, gain armor equal to the result. On a success++, you can immediately take an action.
  • Town's Favor: As an action, call upon the goodwill you've earned in the town. Make an Influence Check. For every success, call upon one townsperson to aid you in some way, such as providing information, creating a distraction, or even joining the fight for one round.
  • Summon Spectacle: (Gain 1 Merchant Token) As an action, spend 1 Merchant Token to create a grand spectacle that summons a spectral performer to aid you. The performer remains for 1 minute, has a basic attack of[[1d4]]physical damage, and has a check of +[[1d4]].
  • Curtain Call: As a reaction, when an enemy misses you with an attack, make an Influence Check. If the result is higher than the enemy's attack roll, you can make an Opportunity Attack, pushing them back 10 ft on a successful hit.
  • Speak to the Manager: (Gain 1 Merchant Token) Spend a Merchant Token to secure a quick conversation with a mayor, leader, or other powerful figure in the local area. They are willing to listen for 1 minute, providing you an opportunity to sway their opinion, gain information, or negotiate a deal.
  • Showman's Gambit: As an action, make a daring move that captures the attention of everyone around you. Make an Influence Check. For every success, impose a Non-Major Condition of your choice on one enemy.
  • Dramatic Entrance: As an action, make a grand entrance that captures everyone's attention. Make an Influence Check. For every success, impose a Cognition condition of your choice on one enemy within sight, such as distracting or disorienting them.
  • Showman's Trick: As an action, perform a quick trick that confuses your enemies. Make a contested Influence Check on a creature you can see. For every success, impose a Corpus condition of your choice on one enemy within sight.
Warlord

Profitable Warlords are merchants of violence, who understand that the clashing of steel is just another form of negotiation. They bring a keen business acumen to the battlefield, turning a profit on their victories and using their wealth to bolster their strength. They are shrewd tacticians and capable fighters, able to broker deals and break bones with equal skill. Their unique understanding of both warfare and commerce makes them formidable adversaries, capable of turning even the direst of situations into opportunities for profit.

Warrior's Investment

The Profitable Warlord understands that war is a costly affair, but the right investments can reap great dividends. By spending a Merchant Token, they can hire a group of mercenaries to assist in battle. These mercenaries follow the Warlord's commands and fight until the end of the battle or until they're defeated. When you spend the token to make an Influence Check, the total is the number of mercenaries at your command. They are outfitted with simple gear and have 3 armor and 3 wounds.

Warlord’s Armor

The warlord suffers no penalties from wearing armor and starts with a set of heavy armor of your choice.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Battlefield Entrepreneur: The Profitable Warlord knows how to capitalize on the chaos of battle. Whenever an enemy is defeated, you gain a small amount of gold or useful items they can sell later. As a reaction when a creature is defeated make a Luck check, each success is +25 gp gained immediately.
  • Investment Recovery: When your mercenaries are defeated in battle, you manage to recover some of your investment. You regain a Merchant Token if none of your mercenaries survive the battle.
  • War Profiteer: (Gain 1 Merchant Token) As a half-action, you can spend a Merchant Token and your armor becomes nearly indestructible. You gain +20 armor for 1 minute. If you have more than 10 armor after the minute, you regain the Merchant Token.
  • Bankroll Blitz: With a keen eye for opportunity, the Profitable Warlord can make a risky investment for a potential high reward. Before an attack, you magically expend 100 gp and deal an additional [[1d6]] Elemental Damage. If the attack misses, the gold is wasted.
  • Marketplace Marauder: The Profitable Warlord knows how to find value in the most unlikely places. Whenever you enter a new location, you can make an Observation check to find valuable items or opportunities for profit, each success is +25 gp gained immediately.
  • Bargain Battler: As an action, magically expend 100 gp and give an ally an additional action on their turn.
  • Golden Opportunity: (Gain 1 Merchant Token) The Profitable Warlord knows that every crisis is an opportunity in disguise. As a reaction whenever an ally fails a combat check, spend a Merchant Token to reroll the check with a +5 bonus. If they succeed, you regain the Merchant Token.
  • Aggressive Negotiations: (Gain 1 Merchant Token) Make a weapon attack as an action and expend 1 Merchant Token, dealing an additional +10 damage. If the creature survives the attack, regain the Merchant Token. Cannot be used on the same creature ever again.
  • Windfall: As an action, make a Survival check and spend 10 gp. On a success, regain 1 wound per success.
  • Armored Tycoon: Your experience in battle has taught you how to get the most out of your armor. At the start of combat, you gain additional strength equal to half your current armor.
Witch

The Witch is a mysterious figure bound to the ancient, untamed forces of nature. Known for brewing potent concoctions and wielding thorned charms, they embody the wild wisdom of the woods, drawing power from plants, animals, and spirits. Whether concocting remedies, commanding vines, or summoning protective spirits, the Witch thrives on their connection to nature and its secrets. Often misunderstood, their magic is one of harmony and preservation, harnessing both beauty and danger to protect and empower.

Briar Charm

With a touch as a half-action, you grant an ally natural armor made of vines and thorns until the end of your next turn, providing them with protection and a wild, intimidating appearance. Attackers face disadvantage on the first attack made against the ally each round, and any creature that makes a melee attack on the ally takes[[1d4]]piercing damage from the thorns.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Herbal Tonic: You can create a herbal tonic that grants minor healing. As a 1 minute action, make a Crafting check. For every success, create a potion that gives [[1d10]] healing. You can have a number of potions equal to your Crafting Check.
  • Vine Grasp: As an action, summon thorny vines to entangle a target within short range. The target must make a Strength check or be pinned. Allies attacking the restrained target gain advantage.
  • Thorny Crown: Create a crown of thorns for an ally, granting them a fierce appearance and causing attackers to hesitate. While wearing the crown, the ally has advantage on Intimidation checks, and any creature that hits them with a melee attack takes[[1d4]]piercing damage. The crown lasts for one hour.
  • Fog Breath: As an action, create a poisonous fog within short range that deals [[1d6]] toxic damage to all creatures that breathe. They must make a Survival check or take the coughing condition.
  • Forest Cloak: Create a cloak of enchanted leaves and bark for you and your allies, giving advantage to Stealth checks. Or create one Forest Cloak of Shadows that gives a creature invisibility until the end of their next turn.
  • Spirit Guide: As an action, summon a PL3 nature spirit as a companion. It remains as long as you choose, but you can only have one spirit at a time. This spirit can scout ahead, providing you with basic information about the environment.
  • Wildwood Empathy: You have an innate connection to animals and plants, allowing you to speak the Naech (general) language. Non-hostile plants and animals may help in minor ways, such as fetching items, warning of danger, or providing knowledge about the area.
  • Nettle Burst: Cast a burst of nettles and thorny plants from your hands, dealing [[1d6]] piercing damage to all creatures in a short range around you.
  • Blessed Briars: Enhances Briar Charm. The charm now grants immunity to the pinned condition while active.
  • Nightshade Tonic: As a 1 minute crafting check, make 1 tonic per success to a maximum number equal to your Crafting Check. The Nightshade tonic gives +1 to all checks for 1 minute. If a creature drinks more than one tonic in a day, they suffer a Major Condition.
Smith

The Smith is a master craftsman who channels their magic and creativity into the art of forging weapons and armor. Whether in the heat of battle or the calm of a workshop, the Smith’s ingenuity and skill ensure their allies are always equipped and ready for the challenges ahead. By infusing their creations with magic, they forge tools of unparalleled power and utility. They can repair, enhance, and even animate their creations to protect themselves and their allies, making them an indispensable part of any adventuring party.

Crafting Spellcaster

You channel magic through the art of creation, making every crafted item a conduit for spells. You cast spells with your Crafting Check and have spell points equal to your Crafting Check.

Rapid Repair

After a long rest, you repair all armor to full for yourself and your party. When you press on, everyone can repair their armor for +5 additional points as you patch them up for the next fight.

Instant Workbench

You carry a collapsible workbench, allowing you to repair armor for +10 points at a time per hour. Additionally, you can enhance a mundane weapon, giving it +3 damage and increasing its value. Each weapon can only be enchanted once.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

Progression Steps

  • Quick Repair: As a 1-minute action, repair a piece of armor or a weapon, restoring it to its maximum armor.
  • Monster's Resilience: Armor you craft gains +10 additional armor.
  • Glyph Dominance: Reduce the difficulty of applying Glyphs by -2.
  • Elemental Smithing: Infuse weapons with elemental energy. Create an enhancement that deals[[1d4]]additional Elemental Damage of your choice.
  • Living Armory: Summon a crafted weapon to fight for you. When unarmed, your crafted weapons animate and act as allies in combat.
  • Smith's Aegis: As an action, hammer the ground to create a protective dome of shimmering energy that provides cover for you and your allies.
  • Smith's Avatar: Infuse a portion of your spirit into a statue or armor stand, animating it as a large, armored guardian to protect your forge or fight for you.
  • Monstrous Glyphster: When crafting and applying Glyphs, gain resilience to potential backlash, improving your chances to prevent equipment destruction during failures.
  • Glyph of Resurrection: Create a glyph that prevents the death condition for 1 hour when the wearer would otherwise die. You can only maintain one of these glyphs at a time.
  • Glyph of Combative Alacrity: Create a glyph that enhances reaction time, giving the user an additional reaction. You can only maintain one of these glyphs at a time.
Merchant Investments

Merchants can enhance their wealth by investing in businesses, which in turn generate more Merchant Tokens. The initial cost and potential returns of these businesses are set by specific guidelines based on their size. Here are some example businesses:

  • Small Business: A local bakery.
  • Medium Enterprise: A town's blacksmith.
  • Large Corporation: A citywide trade network.

Collaborate with your narrator to determine the specifics of your chosen business. Remember, running a business incurs operating costs. For instance, owning a stable implies expenses for horses, maintenance, etc. Though the system simplifies this aspect, players can further integrate their businesses into gameplay, using them as hubs or even hiring other party members.

Business Types

Small Businesses

Business Type Investment Potential Earnings
Baker 3 1
Blacksmith 3 1
Potions Shop 3 1
Tavern 3 1
Boutique 3 1
Newsstand 3 1
Tailor Shop 3 1
Speakeasy 3 1
Barber Shop 3 1
Artisan Furniture 3 1
Stables 3 1

Medium Businesses

Business Type Investment Potential Earnings
Bar or Restaurant 5 2
Trading Post 5 2
Alchemist 5 2
Jazz Club 5 2
Theatre 5 2
Automobile Repair Shop 5 2
Movie Theatre 5 2
Dance Hall 5 2
Radio Station 5 2
Department Store 5 2

Large Businesses

Business Type Investment Potential Earnings
Market Square 7 3
Shipyard 7 3
Magic Emporium 7 3
Trading Company 7 3
Guildhall 7 3
Automobile Dealership 7 3
Luxury Hotel 7 3
Stock Brokerage 7 3
Manufacturing Plant 7 3
Railroad Company 7 3
Monthly Earnings Overview

Each in-game month, Merchants assess the performance of their ventures through an Earnings check. This determines the monthly profit. Factors influencing this check include the business's nature and scale, the game world's economic climate, and notable events of the past month.

For this check, opt for either a d20 or d100 roll. Multiply the result (as a percentage) by your business's potential monthly earnings to calculate your total token profit for that month.

Monthly Business Events

Roll (d20) Roll (d100) Event Percentage
1 1-5 Major Disaster Impacts Business: A significant event such as a flood, fire, or earthquake damages your operations. -5
2 6-10 Supplier Fraud: A supplier provides subpar goods, impacting the quality of your offerings. -4
3 11-15 Economic Downturn: The local economy goes through a downturn, affecting your profits. -3
4 16-20 Security Breach: A security incident, such as a robbery, results in the loss of valuable assets. -2
5 21-25 Quiet Business Period: Business operations maintain a steady pace without significant ups and downs. -1
6 26-30 Staff Training Costs: High staff turnover results in additional training costs and time investment. 0
7 31-35 Increased Productivity: Your team demonstrates exceptional productivity, resulting in increased output. 0
8 36-40 Community Involvement: Your business sponsors a local event, improving your reputation and customer engagement. 0
9 41-45 Local Festival or Event: A local event boosts foot traffic and increases sales. 0
10 46-50 Major Contract Secured: You secure a long-term contract, guaranteeing steady sales. 0
11 51-55 Supplier Negotiation Success: A negotiation with a supplier leads to reduced operational costs. 1
12 56-60 Competitor Closure: A competitor ceases operations, increasing your market share. 2
13 61-65 Innovative Product Launch: A new product or service introduced becomes an instant hit. 3
14 66-70 Successful Marketing Campaign: Your marketing campaign captures attention and boosts sales. 4
15 71-75 Expansion: You open a new location, expanding your customer base and increasing sales. 5
16 76-80 High-Value Patron: A high-value customer frequently engages with your business, making large purchases. 6
17 81-85 Investment Received: An investor makes a significant investment in your business, enabling expansion and increased profits. 7
18 86-90 Unique Sales Opportunity: You acquire a unique item or opportunity that you successfully capitalize on for significant profit. 8
19 91-95 Exclusive Supplier Contract: You negotiate an exclusive agreement, securing a popular product or service that boosts sales. 9
20 96-100 Economic Boom: An economic upturn significantly boosts your sales and profits. 10
Criminal Earnings

Underworld Investments for Merchants

Navigating the darker alleys of commerce, merchants can opt for underworld investments. While these ventures often require less upfront capital, they come with higher risks and potential consequences. The initial outlay and potential returns of these illicit businesses are outlined in specific guidelines, varying by their scale and scope. Here are some example ventures:

  • Small Operations: A discreet alleyway gambling.
  • Medium Enterprises: A smuggling ring.
  • Large Syndicates: A citywide black market network.

The shadowy world of crime offers myriad opportunities. Collaborate with your narrator to detail your chosen venture. But tread carefully; while the costs might be lower, the stakes are higher. Legal repercussions, rival gangs, and moral dilemmas are just some of the challenges you might face. These ventures can also serve as intriguing plot points, bases of operations, or even ensnare other party members in their web.

Small Operations

Operation Type Investment Potential Earnings
Pickpocket Ring 2 1
Fencing Business 2 1
Illegal Potion Brewing 2 1
Illicit Tavern (Selling Contraband) 2 1
Black Market Boutique 2 1

Medium Operations

Operation Type Investment Potential Earnings
Smuggler's Den (Safe House) 4 2
Black Market Trading Post 4 2
Unlicensed Alchemist 4 2
Illegal Beast Trading 4 2
Underground Fighting Ring 4 2

Large Operations

Operation Type Investment Potential Earnings
Dark Market (Trafficking Hub) 6 3
Pirate Haven (Shipyard) 6 3
Illegal Artifact Trafficking 6 3
Underworld Trading Company 6 3
Criminal Syndicate 6 3

Underworld Earnings Overview

For those Merchants embroiled in the underworld, monthly profits are a dance with danger. Every in-game month, perform an Underworld Earnings check to gauge the illicit gains. The outcome can be swayed by the type of operation, its reach, the region's law enforcement vigilance, and unexpected events, such as rival gang confrontations or heists gone wrong.

Choose to roll either a d20 or d100 for this check. Take the result (as a percentage) and multiply it by your venture's potential monthly earnings to deduce your total token haul for the month. But remember, higher rewards often come with greater risks.

Criminal Events

Roll (d20) Event Percentage
1 Major Raid: A significant law enforcement raid results in losses of assets and personnel. -10
2 Snitch: One of your members informs law enforcement about your operations, leading to increased scrutiny. -8
3 Gang War: Conflict with a rival gang disrupts your operations. -6
4 Internal Betrayal: One of your members betrays the organization, leading to loss of assets. -3
5 Quiet Period: Operations continue as usual without significant events. -1
6 Recruitment Drive: You manage to recruit new members, bolstering your operations. 1
7 Successful Heist: Your organization pulls off a major heist, resulting in increased revenue. 2
8 Territory Expansion: You manage to expand your territory, increasing your influence and earnings. 3
9 Protection Racket: You set up a successful protection racket, leading to steady income. 4
10 Law Enforcement Crackdown: Law enforcement cracks down on your activities, but you manage to evade them. 5
11 Successful Smuggling Operation: A smuggling operation goes off without a hitch, increasing your revenue. 6
12 Rival Gang Dismantled: A rival gang gets dismantled by law enforcement, reducing competition. 7
13 Insider Information: You gain insider information, giving you an edge in your operations. 8
14 Blackmail Success: A successful blackmail operation leads to a significant one-time income. 9
15 Major Heist: Your organization pulls off a significant heist, leading to a major increase in income. 10
16 Political Corruption: You manage to corrupt key political figures, leading to decreased scrutiny and increased operations. 11
17 Money Laundering Success: You successfully launder a large amount of money, significantly boosting your income. 12
18 Major Drug Operation: A major drug operation goes off without a hitch, leading to a huge increase in income. 13
19 Takeover of Rival Gang: You manage to take over a rival gang, significantly increasing your territory and income. 14
20 Law Enforcement Infiltration: You successfully infiltrate law enforcement, giving you an edge in your operations and leading to an economic boom for your criminal organization. 15
Mage

As a mage, you are a weaver of magic and a master of mysterious forces. Your power is formidable, but it's also unpredictable, and you'll need a creative mind to control it. Unlike other classes, your spellcasting doesn't rely on a pre-set list of spells. Instead, you combine magic words to create your own unique spells. This path is not without its risks and challenges. Your magic can have both positive and negative outcomes, and it's crucial to learn how to manage these ups and downs. One of the crucial aspects of being a mage is the practice of recording and sharing your knowledge. Whether you pass on your wisdom through spellbooks or spiritual knowledge transfer, your experiences and discoveries become a legacy for future characters you play because they all share your soul.

Remember, as a mage, your journey is a balance of power and wisdom. Your potential is enormous, but the road to mastery is fraught with challenge. You're not merely casting spells - you're shaping reality. Choose your path wisely, and let your knowledge be your legacy.

Class Features & Equipment

Features

  • Spells Known: You gain +3 Spell Points. When you ‘Press On,’ recover an additional Spell Point.

Equipment

Choose one:

  • Arcane Robes: 15 Armor; Movement -20, Stealth -2, Survival -2.
  • Light Armor: 6 Armor; Stealth +1, Agility +1.

Choose one:

  • Staff: Agility; Two-handed, Hefty; Agility as Bludgeoning Damage.
  • Small Weapon: One-handed, Light, Hidden, Throwing Range: Short; 1d4 Physical Damage.
Magical Origin

An Excerpt from the Treatise on Arcane Oppositions by Professor Essley Yahir, the Esteemed Historian of Magic, Magic in all things, and Magical theory, of the Stonetooth Academy of Magic the Gathering:

“In the vast cosmos of magical energies, the origins of magic types are as diverse as the stars in the night sky. Each form of magic, while unique in its essence, finds its place in the grand tapestry of the arcane, often standing in stark opposition to another. This opposition, far from being a source of conflict, is a testament to the balance that governs our universe. Arcane magic, the purest form of magical energy, stands in opposition to the unpredictable and often destructive Chaos magic. Basic magic, the foundation of all magical learning, finds its counter in the complex and time-bending Chronomancy which most regard as the most plot bending of all magics. Celestial magic, drawing its power from the cosmos and heavenly bodies, is opposed by the ground-bound and ancient Vozian magic. Dragon magic, a powerful and ancient form tied to the mythical creatures themselves, is in opposition to Nature magic, which draws its strength from the living world around us, and as many of us know dragons were the first of the outer planar beings to come to Shek. Elemental magic, harnessing the raw power of the natural n elements, stands in contrast to the refined and structured Crystal magic. Life magic, the nurturing force that promotes growth and healing, finds its counter in the mechanical and precise Tech magic.

Understanding these oppositions is not merely an academic exercise. It is a journey towards understanding the fundamental laws that govern our universe and the magical energies that flow within it. As scholars of the arcane, we must strive to understand these relationships, not to exploit them, but to respect the delicate balance they represent and to harness our powers responsibly. Remember, dear students, in the grand scheme of the cosmos, opposition is not about conflict, but about balance and harmony.”

Arcane

Embrace the Arcane Path, where the fabric of reality bends to the will of those daring enough to unlock its secrets. As an adept of arcane mysteries, your spellbook is not merely a collection of incantations; it is the key to unfathomable power, making you a master of the elements, a manipulator of time and space, and a conduit for forces that mere mortals can only dream of wielding. Each page is a testament to your quests for knowledge, filled with spells that can unravel the essence of your foes, shield your allies in impenetrable auras, or even alter the laws of nature to your whim.

Arcane Fizzle

When you cast a spell that fails, you regain half the spent spell points.

Progression

Path progression is linear, you will select these progression steps in order. At level 1, 3, 6 and 9 get an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Whispered Secrets: You can whisper a message that only one designated person can hear, no matter the distance, as long as you know them and they are on the same plane of existence.
  2. Sonorous Echo: When casting a spell, you can choose to delay its effect, activating it later as an off-action up to 3 rounds later.
  3. Repeat Spell: Once per long rest, immediately after casting a spell, you can choose to cast the same spell again on your next turn without spending additional spell points.
  4. Storyteller’s Gift: You can weave intricate, lifelike illusions through your storytelling. These illusions can play out entire scenes, allowing you to perfectly recreate moments from history or spin convincing tales from your imagination. Your illusions can encompass an area of short range but they are easily identified as illusions.
  5. Spell Synergy: Once per long rest, when you cast a spell, you can immediately take an off-action to cast another spell, provided the total spell point cost does not exceed your level.
  6. Whispered Secrets: As an off-action, make a Spellcasting check on an enemy within medium range to cause [[1d6]] Psychic damage, increasing the damage by [[1d6]] per spell point used. Additionally, you can increase the number of targets per spell point used.
  7. Sonorous Echo II: When casting a spell, you can choose to overexert yourself, double the spell and cast it on 2 targets. When you do, you take the exhausted condition until the end of your next turn.
  8. Planar Voice: By expending an additional spell point while casting a spell, you can throw your voice, casting spells from any point within medium range.
  9. Silencing Speech: As an action, you can use your voice to silence another, robbing them of their voice temporarily and preventing them from raising alarms, casting spells, or communicating effectively for 1 minute unless they succeed on a Survival check.
  10. Arcane Wizard: Your command of Magic is absolute. Your words can shape reality, allowing you to cast spells as a half-action.
Basic

You may have been born with magical ability or had an accident at a young age that gave you the ability to shift power as you will. Your magic has a color and effects that are simple but get the job done.

Innate Spellcaster

Gain an additional +5 Spell points.

Progression

Path progression is linear, you will select these progression steps in order. At level 1, 3, 6 and 9 get an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Visual Signature: Your spells manifest with a unique color, visible to all. This color provides a +1 bonus to spellcasting checks.
  2. Efficient Casting: When casting with a "Whisper" intent spell, you can cast using 1 less spell point.
  3. Vicious Spellcasting: Your spell damage base is [[1d6]]. When you increase the damage, it is always at least a [[1d8]].
  4. Spell Shielding: When you cast a spell, gain 3 armor that remains until the end of your next turn or until broken.
  5. Spell Storing: You can store any number of spell points in a rune, vessel, or container of your choosing, allowing you to access them the next day. These stored spell points will only remain until the next day.
  6. Visual Signature II: Increase the bonus to +5 to spellcasting checks.
  7. Efficient Casting II: You can cast magic at a -3 cost.
  8. Vicious Spellcasting II: Your spell damage base is [[3d6]], and damage increase is always at least [[3d8]].
  9. Mana Shield: You are immune to Physical Damage.
  10. Cataclysmic Power: You can cast a Cataclysmic spell intent once per day for no spell points, but immediately take the confused and exhausted conditions for 1 minute.
Celestial

You were blessed by angels or gods, and your power radiates from you even when you're not casting spells. There is a glow about you, and good-aligned creatures say you smell like fresh food and a hug from a lost love. Often, creatures begin to cry around you without explanation.

Radiance Burst

As an off-action, deal 2 Solar damage to creatures you choose in reach range, increasing the range per spell point used.

Progression

Path progression is linear, you will select these progression steps in order. At level 1, 3, 6 and 9 get an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Lightbringer: You can choose to always emit light that glows in a reach range. Additionally, your spells deal an additional +2 Solar damage.
  2. Shielding Light: As a half-action, grant a creature within short range 5 armor made of shimmering light.
  3. Lumière Dure Épée: As an action, create a standard weapon of light that deals Solar damage and lasts for 1 minute. The light can be shaped as any standard melee weapon and can be given to allies. This holy weapon can use Strength, Agility, or your spellcasting check as the attack check.
  4. Eclipse Immunity: You are the defense against the dark; you are immune to Eclipse damage.
  5. Beacon of Hope: As an action, spending 3 spell points, explode with light dealing [[1d6]] Solar damage to all creatures within short range that you choose. If any allies have a cognitive condition, they can make a Survival check to end the effect.
  6. Lightbringer II: Your light expands to a short range, and your spells deal an additional +6 Solar damage.
  7. Shielding Light II: Your light becomes stronger. You can grant 10 armor to an ally within medium range.
  8. Light of Revelation: As an action, burst with light and expose invisible creatures and objects within short range. You can hold this light for 1 minute but cannot use it again for 1 hour.
  9. Aegis of Soul: As a reaction, create a barrier of light that completely negates one attack or spell targeting you or an ally within short range. Additionally, you can choose to banish a target to their home plane of existence if it is of extraplanar origin. They must make a Survival check or become banished. The banishment lasts for at least 1 minute.
  10. Lightforged Avatar: Channeling the core of your radiant powers, you transform into an embodiment of pure energy, becoming an awe-inspiring figure on the battlefield. For 1 minute:
    • Your attacks and spells deal an additional 6d6 radiant damage.
    • You radiate an aura of protection within short range, offering your allies +10 armor and forcing enemies to have disadvantage on their attack rolls.
    • You can negate one spell or attack aimed at you or an ally within the aura, absorbing its power entirely and gaining [[1d6]] spell points.
    • At any moment during this transformation, you can release a wave of radiant energy that either heals your allies or damages your enemies for [[3d6]], expending 3 spell points.
    • This ultimate ability enhances your mobility, doubling your movement speed and providing equal flying speed.
Chaos

Embarking on the Chaos Path is akin to striding into a tempest of arcane unpredictability, where the very essence of magic ebbs and flows with the caprice of the unknown. Those who wield Chaos magic do not do so by the conventional study or lineage but through an innate, often bewildering connection to the arcane. This connection is as volatile as it is powerful, manifesting in bursts of uncontrolled magic that can as easily aid as imperil.

Chaos Control

Every use of a spell that expends spell points is a gamble, tapping into the heart of chaos itself. To channel this force, a Chaos caster must embrace the uncertainty and learn to harness the unpredictable outcomes.

When casting a spell that uses spell points, roll a 1d6 on the Chaos Table to determine the spell's augmented effect:

  1. Wild Surge: The spell expands beyond your target, affecting all creatures within reach. Allies and enemies alike are swept up in the spell's effect, creating a maelstrom of magic around the point of casting.
  2. Power Flux: The arcane energies fluctuate wildly, either consuming double the spell points for normal effectiveness or sapping the spell's strength, halving its impact while expending the usual amount.
  3. Elemental Twist: The spell's nature warps, transforming into a different Elemental Damage type. Fire might become ice, lightning could turn to acid, reflecting the chaotic heart of the spell's origin.
  4. Mana Redux: In a rare moment of clarity, the chaotic magic refunds half the spell points used, as if the spell weaves through the threads of chaos to replenish your arcane reserves.
  5. Mana Shield: The chaotic energy coalesces into a protective aura, granting 5 armor that shields you from harm until the end of your next turn.
  6. Wild Empowerment: Magic, unbridled and unrestrained, flows through you without cost. The spell casts at its highest potential without expending spell points, a testament to the raw power of chaos.

Progression

Path progression is linear, you will select these progression steps in order. At level 1, 3, 6, and 9 get an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Introduction to Chaos: Learn to slightly influence the roll on the Chaos Table, allowing a reroll once per long rest.
  2. Control Surge: Increase the area affected by Wild Surge to short range. Now, your spells also push affected targets away from the spell's epicenter by +10ft.
  3. Defensive Chaos: Whenever you activate Mana Shield from the Chaos Table, it also reflects up to 5 damage back to melee attackers for its duration.
  4. Enhanced Empowerment: Spells affected by Wild Empowerment gain an additional minor effect based on their element (e.g., fire spells briefly ignite the area, ice spells can slow).
  5. Improved Mana Redux: Increase the effectiveness of Mana Redux. Now regain full spell points spent on the casting.
  6. Control Surge II: Wild Surge only affects creatures of your choice.
  7. Flux Control: When you get Power Flux on the Chaos Table, nothing happens instead of the negative effects.
  8. Spell Duplication: Spells that do not require spell points due to Wild Empowerment leave an arcane echo that can be triggered on your next turn for a reduced effect without additional cost.
  9. Enhanced Empowerment II: Your spells deal dual damage types. You choose which table to roll when dealing with success+ outcomes.
  10. Chaos Unleashed: Gain the ability to cast directly from the Chaos Table, choosing the desired outcome instead of leaving it to chance. However, when you do, you anger the gods of Chaos, and they may send chaos creatures to stop you.
Chronomancy

You've seen what happens next, and you are trying your best to change the events from the future in the past. Your magic often manifests as clocks, sundials, or similar timekeeping motifs. The power of Chronus flows through you, granting you insight into the flow of time and the ability to manipulate it to your advantage.

Premonition

You briefly glimpse into the future and gain insight into the actions of your enemies. As an Off-Action on your turn, make an Observation check. On a success, you gain advantage on any checks against them until the end of your turn.

Progression

Path progression is linear, you will select these progression steps in order. At level 1, 3, 6, and 9 get an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Visionary Strike: When you make a successful Observation Check using Premonition, your next attack against a target deals additional [[1d6]] psychic damage.
  2. Psychic Shield: When you succeed on an Observation Check using Premonition, you learn a target’s motivation, wounds, armor, or some other truth about the target.
  3. Temporal Step: When you use Premonition, you can teleport to the creature if they are within medium range.
  4. Unraveling Gaze: As a half-action, spend a spell point to see through illusions, detect sources of magic, and pierce magical darkness.
  5. Unseen Path: As an action, you speak to your past and future self to determine the best course of action by making an Observation Check. On a success, you gain advantage for 1 minute on non-combat checks. On a failure, you gain the attention of the time wardens.
  6. Timeless Rewind: You gain advantage on Observation Checks related to history and the future. Once per long rest, you can turn back time 1 round, undoing one event or preventing a mistake. This action gathers the attention of the time wardens.
  7. Glimpse of Eternity: As an Off-Action, you can gain advantage on any one check, attack roll, or saving throw. You no longer age and cannot be magically aged.
  8. Shared Visions and Future Sight: You can grant the benefits of your Premonition ability to your allies. You also gain the ability to see invisible and intangible creatures up to reach range.
  9. Chrono Shift: Once per long rest, take [[1d4]] turns consecutively. This will anger the time wardens.
  10. Master Oracle: You can use your Premonition ability as a Free Action and can affect a number of targets equal to your Observation Check. The bonus damage from Visionary Strike increases to [[3d6]] psychic damage, and you can teleport a medium range using Temporal Step.
Crystal

You use, break, and wear crystals of all kinds and colors. They grant you the power to cast powerful spells and abilities. You have power over crystals that give you interesting abilities over resonance and structure.

Resonant Piezoelectric

As an action, fire a blast of sonic energy in a short range line that deals [[2d4]] thunder damage to all the creatures in the line. Increase the damage by +1d6 per spell point used.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9, gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Crystalline Focus: This refined crystal enhances your sonic manipulations, providing advantage on Observation checks.
  2. Crystallographic Memory: Store visual and auditory information within crystals, creating detailed recordings that can be played back at any time. This can include capturing scenes, conversations, or secretive meetings.
  3. Crystal Echoes: Whenever you use Resonant Piezoelectric, the energy echoes, allowing you a second blast as an off-action dealing half damage.
  4. Vibrational Therapy: Develop therapeutic techniques using crystal vibrations to treat psychological or emotional distress. You can remove any Cognitive Conditions on allies as a half-action.
  5. Mana Resonance: Whenever you use Resonant Piezoelectric, you can cast a spell that costs no spell points as an off-action.
  6. Vibrational Shield: Whenever you use Resonant Piezoelectric, gain armor equal to the damage dealt.
  7. Frequency Modulation: Your Resonant Piezoelectric pushes large or smaller creatures in the line 10ft in a direction of your choice.
  8. Piercing Resonance: Your mastery over sonic energy allows you to pierce through magical defenses. Your Resonant Piezoelectric can now also damage intangible creatures and penetrate barriers such as magical shields.
  9. Resonant Synergy: Combine the effects of Crystal Echoes and Mana Resonance. When using Resonant Piezoelectric, you can now cast a spell as an off-action at full effectiveness while also unleashing a secondary blast.
  10. Resonant Cataclysm: Your Resonant Piezoelectric becomes an area effect within a short range that affects only creatures you choose.
Dragon

You were blessed by a dragon or you have a draconic bloodline. The power of Khalas, the god dragon, compels you. You feel the need to travel to the dragon island at least once in your life.

Scaleskin

You were born with dragon magic within you. Scales spot your skin. You start with +1 to all your checks.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9, gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Scaled Resilience: Your skin toughens, providing a natural defense that grants +5 armor that can be healed or repaired.
  2. Ancient Insight: Tap into the collective wisdom of dragonkind to gain advantage on Intellect and Survival checks related to magic, history, or the natural world.
  3. Fiery Exhalation: As an action, unleash a cone of dragonfire that deals [[1d10]] fire damage to all creatures in front of you up to reach range.
  4. Aerial Surge: Gain the ability to make a powerful leap up to your movement speed as an off-action.
  5. Terrifying Presence: As a half-action, emit a fearsome roar that can intimidate foes if they fail an Influence check, giving them disadvantage on their next check against you, once per long rest.
  6. Scaled Resilience II: You have a natural armor of +10 that regenerates on a long rest.
  7. Fiery Exhalation II: Your dragonfire now deals [[3d10]] fire damage.
  8. Wings Unfurled: Summon ethereal dragon wings that grant you the ability to fly with a speed equal to your movement.
  9. Scaleskin II: You have a +3 to all checks.
  10. Draconic Ascendance: Embrace the full might of your draconic heritage, allowing you to transform into a full dragon form once per long rest. This transformation grants +30 armor, makes your size large, gives you a fly speed equal to double your movement, and allows you to carry up to 5 medium creatures easily.
Elemental

You are a conduit of elemental power. Through you, the elements unite and empower your spells: the solidity of stone, the fervor of fire, the fluidity of water, and the whisper of air; all combining to form a tapestry of elemental mastery.

Elemental Absorption

once per long rest, if you are hit with elemental damage, gain armor equal to the damage instead of taking damage.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9, gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Fire Affinity: Your command over flames grants you power. All your spells now deal an additional +2 fire damage.
  2. Lightning Affinity: Your restless energy manifests; you are never in one place for long. As an action, dash in a short-range line as a lightning bolt that does not provoke opportunity attacks, dealing [[1d4]] damage to all creatures in that line.
  3. Ice Affinity: The cold empowers you. As an off-action, coat your skin in ice, giving 3 armor. If hit with a melee attack, deal 1 ice damage to the attacker.
  4. Air Affinity: The winds lift you. You hover slightly above the ground and don't trigger traps that require a weight trigger. Additionally, increase movement speed by 10ft.
  5. Stone Affinity: The strength of the stone is at your call. Create 6 stone armor as a half-action that remains until the end of your next turn.
  6. Water Affinity: As an action, you become one with liquid that is at least half water and can contain your entire body. When you do so, you are indiscernible from the liquid and take on the same color, making you invisible and unable to be targeted or touched by any physical means. If the water takes damage, you take half the damage.
  7. Smoke Affinity: Embrace the shadows, smoke, and darkness. As an action, exhale smoke to blind and cause coughing on a target within reach range if they fail a Survival check until the end of their next turn.
  8. Fire Affinity II: Your spells deal an additional +5 fire damage.
  9. Elemental Absorption II: Gain double the damage as armor.
  10. Elemental Avatar: Take the form of all the elements, becoming a storm of elemental fury that lasts for 1 minute. You double your movement, gain flight equal to your movement, +50 armor, and your attacks deal elemental damage equal to half your armor. However, you cannot cast spells during this time.
Nature

You were probably born under an old willow tree that planted a seed in your belly when you took your first breath. The tree dies, and now you have the magic within you. When you pass, you will become the tree and pass your power on to another.

Tree Speech

You can speak Naech (general), which allows you to communicate with plants and animals. They respond to you in one-word answers.

Nature Spirit

You have a +3 Loyalty with trees and +4 Spirit.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9, gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Thorny Defense: You move silently and leave no tracks on natural ground. Additionally, as an action, summon a circle of brambles around your reach range that deals [[1d4]] piercing damage and creates difficult terrain.
