  2. Animal Empathy: Form a deeper bond with animals you encounter, making them more inclined to assist or accompany you on your journey. You can speak to them, and you and your party can understand them while interacting with the creature.
  3. Veil of Leaves: As an action, blend into natural surroundings with ease, becoming invisible when motionless in foliage or shaded areas.
  4. Flourishing Terrain: Transform a short-range area into lush, difficult terrain that hampers foes but accelerates healing and gains [[1d4+2]] spell points per hour for you and allies standing within it. Within the terrain, you can create hammocks, beds, or furniture of your choice. There is drinking water, fruit, and small animals that wander into the area.
  5. Animal Companion: Form a bond with a creature of the wild, summoning it as an action at PL4 +1 per spell point used, to your side once per long rest to assist in combat or perform simple tasks.
  6. Wild Shape: As an action, gain the ability to transform into a small or medium animal, adopting its physical forms and abilities from the beast table. It requires an action to return to your true form.
  7. Unerring Path: Never lose your way in the Feywild or enchanted forests, always able to find paths, even those hidden by magic.
  8. Charm of the Fey: As an action, make an Influence Check and charm an individual on a success for 1 minute, making them more amicable and open to suggestions, tell you secrets, or follow you. After the minute, they may realize they have been charmed and might become hostile.
  9. Nature’s Wrath: Your spells deal nature damage by default.
  10. Eternal Guardian: As an action, embody the full power of nature, gaining the ability to transform into a mighty tree form. In this form, you gain +30 armor, can heal allies for +10 within medium range each turn as an off-action, and have an aura that gives enemies -3 to their checks for 1 minute. Once the minute is complete, you enter a coma-like sleep for 1 hour and cannot be awoken during this time.
Life

Whether it be your life or another’s, you wield it as a power of your own. This can be your blood or the plants and animals around you. After you cast spells, you and things around you have a little less brightness to them.

Not Yet

If you take the Death Condition, make a Luck check. On a success, you remove the death condition. This cannot be used again for 1 month.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9, gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Shared Vitality: As an action touching a creature, temporarily link your life force with an ally's, allowing you to transfer your health to them or vice versa up to your maximum wounds. This connection leaves both parties feeling momentarily drained and pale.
  2. Revitalization: once per long rest as an action, draw deeply from the life force of the land to invigorate yourself, granting +3 strength and agility for 1 minute at the cost of the area's vitality, leaving it grey and lifeless.
  3. Life Cycle: Upon using "Not Yet" to avoid the Death Condition, your revival leaves a mark of desolation on the surroundings, and your form becomes slightly more spectral, but you gain +2 spell points permanently.
  4. Speak with Dead: Communicate with the spirits of the deceased, extracting information or promises of service in exchange for temporary peace. You always have a PL1 minion of your choice like a skeleton, ghoul, or raven that returns to life after 1 minute if it is killed, or instantly by spending 1 spell point.
  5. Borrowed Time: Store a portion of your life force (like permanent wounds or spell points) in a soul-container object, giving it an eerie glow or darkness. You can tap into this reserve in moments of need, though doing so emits an eerie, decaying energy.
  6. Life’s Ascension: You can use "Not Yet" once per long rest with an automatic success. When you do, you retain the wounds of the loss. Your bones become brittle, taking the Broken and Dislocation conditions upon your resurrection. You need to spend 3 spell points to remove them or have an ally heal them.
  7. Aura of Decay: As an action, release a fog that saps vitality from enemies to heal your wounds. This deals [[1d10]] elemental damage to creatures within reach range, healing you for half the total damage dealt. The land it touches withers, and the life force it drains manifests as brief flickers of light rushing towards you.
  8. Minions: You have weak minions that follow you and can perform tasks at your bidding. These tasks can be simple, and they will do their best. You have a number of minions equal to your Luck check or a single minion with a PL equal to your Luck check.
  9. Borrowed Time II: You can store all but 1 wound in your Soul-Container. When you activate "Not Yet," your body dissipates and returns to life wherever the soul-container resides in [[1d6]] days. Your minions will protect your Soul-Container, but powerful creatures will be drawn to it.
  10. Life Path Transformation: Complete your descent into darkness by becoming a master of life. You no longer age, and your physical form becomes a vessel for magic. You command legions of the un-living and wield Eclipse magic with unparalleled mastery. Your very presence blights the land, and you can draw upon the life force of your minions to sustain your spells and existence.
Tech

An architect of the arcane and the mechanical, you've merged cutting-edge technology with mystic energies. As a Tech Mage, your body not only hosts cybernetic enhancements but also serves as a conduit for potent magical forces. You craft and wield gadgets that are not only marvels of engineering but also enchanted instruments capable of channeling powerful spells.

Robot Limb

Either on accident or through experimentation, you've replaced a limb with a robotic one. Your arm provides 10 armor, and as an action, you can regain [[1d10]] armor (granting temporary armor if above maximum) and gain +2 to checks and damage until the end of your next turn.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9, gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Customizable Limb: Your robot limb can be outfitted with various tools and gadgets that assist in mundane tasks and can be swapped or upgraded over time. Your robot limb grants +1 Strength and +1 Agility.
  2. Portable Storage: A lightweight, extra-dimensional pouch that expands internally to hold small items. It can carry multiple tools, trinkets, or materials without adding encumbrance.
    • Capacity: Up to 10 bulk (items cannot exceed 2 bulk individually).
    • Access Time: Off-Action to store or retrieve.
    • Living Creatures: Tiny creatures (up to 1 bulk) can be stored temporarily for up to 1 hour with breathable air. Discomfort begins after 5 minutes.
  3. Illusory Displays: As an action, project detailed illusions and holographic maps with a portable, crank-powered device. This apparatus is perfect for planning heists, exploring unknown territories, or creating diversions. It remains for as long as you power it as an off-action on your turns and projects up to short range.
  4. Rapid Recharge: As an action, you can choose to Overclock your tech to rapidly regain [[1d6]] spell points that last until the end of your next turn.
  5. Analytical Vision: A sophisticated monocle enhances your sight, granting the ability to closely inspect and analyze magical residues and mechanical workings, giving +1 Observation.
  6. Rapid Recharge II: Instead of Overclock, you can use Overburn, which as a half-action gains [[2d4]] spell points until the end of your next turn.
  7. Drone Companion: As an action, construct a small drone using spare parts and magic. This drone is a PL3 and can perform reconnaissance, deliver spells stored in your tech, or assist in crafting and repair tasks.
  8. Shield Matrix: As a reaction, activate a shield matrix that grants armor equal to your Crafting check. This shield lasts for 1 minute or until depleted, protecting you from physical and magical attacks by absorbing damage.
  9. Field Control: Employ technology to manipulate gravity around you, enabling high jumps, slow falls, or the pulling and pushing of objects without physical contact.
  10. Quantum Calibration: Calibrate your tech to tap into quantum energies, allowing you to, as an Off-Action (Reaction), reroll any failed spellcasting check or have a creature reroll a successful check against your spells once.
Vozian

You choose to draw on the most evil energy you can. Ash falls from you wherever you step, your skin is dry and cracked, and the skin underneath is dark and tar-like. Demons speak to you as casual friends would, and bright lights feel like whips to your skin.

One of You

Demons, Devils, and other creatures born of evil have a +2 loyalty with you. If you acquire the true name of a demon, they become your servant.

Failure Gains

If you fail a spell and Stress Push to succeed, gain armor instead of losing health.

Progression

Path progression is linear; you will select these progression steps in order. At levels 1, 3, 6, and 9, gain an increase of +3 points to put into your checks, but no check can exceed 15. Additionally, gain +2 Spell points at each of these levels as well.

Progression Steps

  1. Infernal Knowledge: Unlock knowledge of demonic lore and the ability to communicate with all demons telepathically, gaining insights and potentially persuading them to share truths or aid.
  2. Infernal Sight: Double your low-light vision. Your eyes adapt to see clearly in both absolute darkness and blinding light, though bright natural light still discomforts you.
  3. Duskwalker: As an action, embrace the shadows to become invisible until the end of your next turn.
  4. Dominion's Resilience: The Iron Dominion toughens you. You have +10 natural armor that recovers double on Press On and fully on a long rest.
  5. Cauterizing Flames: As an action, your touch can summon hellfire that heals or harms for [[1d6]] Vozian damage without a check. Use it to cauterize wounds, sealing them with dark energy leaving terrible scars, or to ignite enemies with a corrupt flame.
  6. Ethereal Familiar: As an action, summon a PL4 demonic familiar bound to serve you. This familiar can perform tasks, spy for you, and assist in casting spells, especially those with Vozian energy. They remain until dismissed, though they do not want to be there.
  7. Dimensional Shift: As an action, roll [[1d10-1]] to step into that layer of the Ordealis, greeted by a familiar lesser demon of that layer.
  8. Frostwalker: Immune to Ice damage and able to traverse icy terrains effortlessly. Your presence may quell blizzards or summon frost to hinder foes.
  9. Judgment’s Insight: Gain a deep understanding of moral and ethical dilemmas, giving you advantage on Influence checks. This allows you to navigate complex social interactions and detect lies or hidden motives with uncanny accuracy.
  10. Ordealis Ascendant: Achieve a profound connection with Ordealis itself, enabling you to draw upon its entropic energies to cast powerful spells that deal Vozian damage without the need to spend additional spell points. As an action, summon greater demons at PL10 without spell points, though they will not be under your command.
Mana Pools (Talent)

Mana Pools serve as the mage's wellspring of magical energy, a core aspect distinguishing their capabilities and defining their unique connection to the arcane. Unlike talents, which may rely on innate skill or physical prowess, Mana Pools tap directly into the raw essence of magic itself. Each mage draws from their own distinct source of power, shaping the spells they cast and the magic they wield. Below are several Mana Pool options, each offering a different origin for a mage's magical power

Galeforce

You harness the essence of motion and speed, casting spells that enhance swiftness or slow down foes. Your Agility Check determines your spellcasting check. You have Spell Points equal to your Agility Check. Regain 1 spell point on a Press On, all on a long rest. Additionally, gain 1 spell point by successfully avoiding an attack or trap using your agility.

Gale Step

As an action, teleport short range with a burst of wind. Upon arrival, all creatures within 5ft must make a Strength check or be knocked prone.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

  • Gale Step Enhancement: Gale Step becomes medium range. Upon arrival, generate a gust granting temporary armor points equal to your Agility Check until the end of your next turn.
  • Whirling Defense: As a Half-Action, summon ethereal blades that orbit you for 1 minute, automatically dealing [[1d4]] thunder damage to nearby enemies at the end of your turn.
  • Zephyr's Grace: You float slightly above the ground, leaving no footprints and avoiding pressure traps entirely.
  • Wind's Embrace: Gain the ability to hover or fly up to your movement speed at low altitudes, landing at the end of your turn.
  • Stormcaller's Command: Control local weather to create gusts or downdrafts, affecting enemy movements or assisting allies within a medium range.
  • Gale Step Mirage: Upon using Gale Step, you create a visual illusion of yourself at the departure point that lasts for a few seconds. This mirage can draw attacks or attention away from your true location, offering strategic distractions or confusions in combat or tense situations.
  • Gale Step Breeze: After using Gale Step, a soothing breeze remains, calming emotions within a small radius. This can be used to de-escalate conflicts, soothe frightened individuals, or provide relief in stressful situations, making it a versatile tool for non-combat encounters.
  • Gale Step Zephyr: Upon using Gale Step, the air around your arrival point becomes charged with energy. For a short duration, allies within this area receive a minor boost to their agility and reaction time, making it an excellent tactic for initiating surprise attacks or swiftly evading danger.
  • Gale Step Echoes: Your mastery over Gale Step allows you to create auditory illusions at both your departure and arrival points. These sounds can range from footsteps to your voice, offering complex strategies for deception, misdirection, and communication over distances.
  • Air Cushion: As your reaction, create a cushion of air to catch falling objects or to soften impacts, potentially preventing damage to fragile items or cushioning a fall.
Artifex

Your magic is in creation and transformation, casting spells that fabricate objects or alter materials. Your Crafting Check is your spellcasting check. You have Spell Points equal to your Crafting Check. Regain 1 spell point on a Press On, all on a long rest. Additionally, gain 1 spell point by crafting an item or successfully repairing something significant.

Mage Artisan

Once per long rest, you can craft a temporary magical item without the need for materials. This magical item is imbued with a spell you craft with your words of power that has a feature you design. This item lasts for 24 hours and is a standard weapon unless otherwise specified.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

  • Imbue Essence: As a half-action spending 1 spell point, you can imbue weapons or objects with magical essences, switching its damage to an elemental type of your choice for 1 minute.
  • Wondrous Tinker: Gain the ability to repair magical items, restoring a portion of their power or functionality. This process can also temporarily boost the item's effectiveness, granting bonus effects or enhanced power.
  • Phantom Smithy: You have a spectral forge and tools that follow you and can be summoned and set as an action. You can perform crafting actions on the go, without the need for a physical workshop. This mobile smithy allows for the repair and creation of items anywhere.
  • Architect of the Arcane: As an action, design and construct a small, temporary magical structure, such as a bridge, shelter, or tower. These structures last for 24 hours and can be tailored to suit immediate needs, such as defense, rest, or strategic advantage. Cannot be summoned on top of living creatures.
  • Whispers of the Blade: As a 1-hour crafting check, bestow sentience upon your crafted weapons. These weapons gain the ability to communicate telepathically with their wielder and provide advantage on one attack roll per long rest due to their tactical guidance.
  • Temporal Edge: As a 1-hour crafting check, infuse a weapon with the essence of time. Once per long rest, the wielder can rewind a moment, essentially granting them a redo of a missed attack or failed save.
  • Mana Disruptor: As a 1-hour crafting check, create a device capable of emitting a pulse that temporarily disables magical traps, constructs, or barriers within a reach range. Usable once per long rest.
  • Fortified Bastion: As a 1-hour crafting check, enchant a structure to act as a formidable bastion, significantly enhancing its durability and creating defensive mechanisms such as magical barriers, automated defenses, and traps to protect against attackers.
  • Transportation Nodes: As a 1-hour crafting check, craft teleportation nodes that are within 1 mile of one another. You can have a number of nodes equal to half your Crafting Check, and they last for 1 year before they need to be maintained. These nodes cannot teleport creatures of an opposite magic from your magic path and can drive these creatures insane.
  • Ethereal Library: Construct a magical library that can store and catalog vast amounts of information magically. Access to the library grants advantage on Intellect checks and can reveal insights on specific topics, creatures, or spells when spending 1 hour in the library.
Heartflow

Your spells sway minds and hearts, casting enchantments that manipulate emotions and convictions. Your Influence Check serves as your spellcasting check. You have Spell Points equal to your Influence Check. Regain 1 spell point on a Press On, all on a long rest. Gain an additional spell point by convincing someone to change their mind or by successfully navigating a difficult social encounter in your favor.

Heartstring Tug

When making an Influence check, you can spend Spell Points to increase the check by +1 per point spent. Additionally, when you get a success+ on an Influence check, a single target takes the charmed condition.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

  • Empathic Resonance: As an off-action, you can read the emotional state of any individual you're conversing with, gaining advantage on your next Influence check against them. This allows you to tailor your approach for maximum effect.
  • Whispered Inception: In a conversation, you can implant a subtle suggestion in the listener's mind. If you succeed on an Influence check with a success+, the target feels compelled to act on your suggestion as if it was their own idea, provided it doesn't bring direct harm to them or others.
  • Aura of Allure: Your presence becomes irresistibly captivating to those around you. Allies within a 15-foot radius gain a bonus to their own Charisma-based checks, drawn from your magnetic energy.
  • Diplomatic Immunity: As an action, spend 1 Spell Point to make yourself and your allies within reach range immune to being charmed or frightened until the end of your next turn, reflecting your deep understanding of emotional manipulation.
  • Harmonic Persuasion: When working together with an ally on an Influence attempt, you can combine your efforts seamlessly, granting you both a bonus to the check. This represents your skill in orchestrating social situations to your advantage.
  • Mirror Heart: You can reflect the emotions of one person onto another within your vicinity. This can be used to spread calm, joy, or even dissent, manipulating group dynamics subtly.
  • Binding Promise: When you charm someone with Heartstring Tug, you can bind the charm with a promise. If the target agrees to a task or action and breaks this promise, they suffer a minor magical penalty, such as a headache or a sense of unease, encouraging them to keep their word.
  • Veil of Composure: You can mask your true emotions and intentions, making it nearly impossible for others to discern your lies or truths. This grants you a defensive mechanism against those who would use your own tactics against you.
  • Symphony of Minds: As a pinnacle of your influence abilities, you can extend your charm effect to a small group, weaving their emotions and thoughts together in a harmonious symphony that aligns with your goals. This grand manipulation, however, requires careful planning and expenditure of multiple Spell Points to maintain control without backlash.
Mindrift

Your magic is the pursuit of knowledge and arcane secrets, casting spells that unlock mysteries or enhance understanding. Your Intellect Check is your spellcasting check. You have Spell Points equal to your Intellect Check. Regain 1 spell point on a Press On, all on a long rest. Gain an additional spell point by acquiring new knowledge or solving a complex puzzle or problem.

Mana Insight

As an action, spend 1 spell point to reveal magical traps, enchantments, or the presence of magical creatures within a short range for the next minute. This insight allows you to understand the basic properties of the revealed magic, such as its effect, strength, and potential origin.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

  • Arcane Efficiency: Your spells cost 2 less to cast, allowing you to weave magic with effortless grace.
  • Tracking Spell: By spending an additional 2 spell points when you hit a creature with a spell, you can leave a “trace” on any magical effect or creature you detect. For the next 24 hours, you can sense the direction and general distance of this effect or creature if it is within 5 miles.
  • Soul Exchange: Sacrifice 2 wounds to regain 1 spell point, a testament to your dedication or desperation.
  • Knowledge Recovery: once per long rest, as an action, read an entire book and regain [[2d6]] spell points. It must be a new book each time.
  • Memory Smith: As an action, spending 3 spell points, you and up to 3 other creatures dive into the memory of a creature you can touch if they fail an Intellect check. The experience feels like 1 hour while in the memory but only takes until the end of your next turn.
  • Word Wrangler: You can cast two spells at once. Both spells must target the same creature.
  • Reactive Spellweaver: You can cast single spell point spells or less as an off-action.
  • Mana Bulwark: Create +10 armor for yourself. If the shield is depleted, you may recharge it as an action for 2 spell points. Alternatively, spend 1 spell point to extend armor of +3 per spell point to allies within short range until the end of your next turn.
  • Stealth Caster: Your spells leave no visible or audible signs of casting, making your magic undetectable except by its effects.
  • Arcane Sanctum: As an action, spend 1 spell point to create a Sanctuary of Reflection, a mental library filled with mirrors reflecting moments of your accumulated knowledge. Creatures resting in the Sanctuary gain advantage on their next Intellect-based check and can ask one question, which the Sanctuary answers based on your knowledge.
Prophecy

You bend fortune to your will, casting spells that manipulate probabilities and chance. Your magic is unpredictable, your Luck Check is your check for spellcasting. You have Spell Points equal to your Luck Check. Regain 1 spell point on a Press On, all on a long rest. Gain an additional spell point each time you experience a stroke of good luck or a favorable turn of events deemed significant by the narrator.

Prophecy Pool

You have 3 additional spell points that recover 1 on a Press On and one on a long rest. Expend 3 spell points to gain a prophecy point.

Prophecy Dice

For each prophecy point acquired, roll a d20. Record the result and add it to your prophecy pool. When making any check, you can use a reaction to replace your roll with a number from your prophecy pool, consuming that recorded number. You can have up to 3 dice stored in your pool.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

  • Unseen Servant: As an action using a spell point, summon a version of you from the past, an ancestor, or spirit of your choosing that lasts for 1 minute. It takes actions on your turn.
  • Echo: When you make a spell attack and the roll lands on a 5, cast the spell again at no cost.
  • Hand of Fate: Expend a prophecy die and gain a [[1d6]] . This [[1d6]] can be added to anyone’s check within short range of you as an Off-Action.
  • Speak with the Dead: Over 1 minute, you can question a corpse. The corpse must have been dead for no longer than 10 days and must be able to answer the questions. The corpse answers with one sentence per question, and will answer 3 questions or more if it desires. After 1 minute the corpse turns to dust.
  • Speak with Fate: Over 10 minutes, make a Spirit check while you focus on a course of action. On a success, Fate gives a single word or image based on what you focused on. This may provide insight, give you a clue, or warn you about a path or potential outcome.
  • Reverse Pain: Spend a prophecy die to heal a creature for [[1d4]] wounds, 1 injury, or remove 1 condition.
  • Temporal Shift: As a reaction, use 3 spell points to briefly shift yourself into the past, allowing an incoming attack to pass harmlessly through you.
  • Echoes of the Past: As an action, use 3 spell points to recall a past event in vivid detail that happened in this area. This can provide useful information or clues about the current situation.
  • Temporal Insight: As an action, use 3 spell points to glimpse into your own past and future or at least one version of them, giving you insight into the possible outcomes of your current situation if certain choices you may have made caused a particular outcome.
Visionary

Your magic is intuitive, born from a deep understanding of your surroundings. You cast spells by observing and reacting to the environment, using your Observation Check. Spell points equal your Observation Check. Regain 1 spell point on a Press On, all on a long rest. Gain an additional spell point each time you spot something hidden or invisible, notice a secret, or spot a danger before others that keeps everyone safe.

Insight

Your acute observations allow you to channel magical energy with precision, infusing your spells with the essence of your surroundings. You have a resource of 3 Insight points. You can expend a point to gain advantage on a spell, uncover truths, find hidden objects, or remove the invisible or intangible condition. Regain 1 point on a Press On, all on a long rest.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

  • Echoes of Intent: Your keen observation allows you to sense the intentions of others, granting you the ability to predict enemy movements. As a free action, spend an Insight point to take a stance if you are not already in one.
  • Beyond Sight: Your observational skills pierce through deception. You can detect illusions and magically hidden objects or creatures within short range.
  • Whispers: By observing the flows of magic around you, you can listen to the whispers of arcane energy. This grants you insight into the magical abilities of observed creatures, identifying one spell or magical effect they can produce, which you can then prepare defenses against.
  • Temporal Awareness: Your acute observations extend to the flow of time itself. Once per long rest, freeze a moment in time to analyze the battlefield, granting you an extra action on your turn, which must be used for analysis, spell preparation, or observation.
  • Mindscape Navigation: Delve into the mental landscapes of those you observe. Once per long rest, you and your party can enter the mind of a willing or incapacitated creature, exploring their thoughts for clues, secrets, or information as if navigating a physical space.
  • Reality's Weave: Your observation of reality's fabric allows you to tug on its threads. As an action, spend 1 Insight point to alter one minor detail of your environment once per long rest (e.g., unlocking a door, turning a pathway), as long as it doesn't directly harm another being.
  • Echo: When you uncover a hidden truth or attempt to reveal something invisible with an Insight point and nothing is presented, regain the expended point.
  • Perspective Switch: As an Off-Action, spend 1 Insight point to make all creatures within short range view the world from your perception until the end of your next turn. They understand your thoughts and ideas, and you can convey any truth or memory about yourself. When they return, they must make an Observation check or gain +1 Loyalty to you.
  • Whimsical Warp: As an action, spend 1 Insight point to bend space and swap positions with a random object within sight. This can be anything from a book to a chair, as long as you fit in the space and it is not anchored or too large.
  • Gravity's Suggestion: As a half-action, spend 1 Insight point to perceive gravity differently. For the next minute, you can walk on walls or ceilings. The effect ends if you take damage.
Soulstream

Your spells connect to the ethereal and the divine, manipulating the fabric of reality itself. Your Spirit Check is your spellcasting check. You have Spell points equal to your Spirit Check. Regain 1 spell point on a Press On, all on a long rest. Additionally, gain 1 spell point by performing a spiritual or religious act that aligns with your beliefs or magic source.

Possession

As an action, touch a creature and attempt to possess it with a contested Spirit check. If you succeed, you become intangible and merge with the targeted creature until the end of your next turn. While possessing a creature, you have full physical control, sensory access, communication, and limited memory observation (only surface-level thoughts). You cannot cast your spells, damage the host, or cause damage to the host's loyalties. If the host takes damage, they can make the Spirit check again, adding a bonus to the check equal to the damage taken. If the host regains control, you are pushed from the body, knocked prone within 5 feet in a direction of your choice, and take the confused condition until the end of your next turn.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

  • Spiritual Echo: When casting a spell, spend an additional 1 spell point to leave a faint spiritual echo in the area. For the next hour, you can sense the presence of living creatures moving through this echo, as the spirits alert you to intruders or dangers, enhancing your guardianship over a domain.
  • Ethereal Passage: Spend 2 spell points to become intangible, stepping into the world of spirits.
  • Ancestral Guidance: Gain the ability to summon a spirit guide as an off-action. The guides will provide you with a +5 bonus on one check of your choice, but you take the confused condition until the end of your next turn.
  • Blessing of the Ancestors: As a half-action, call upon your ancestors to bless one ally within short range. The ally gains advantage on their next chosen check.
  • Ward Against Evil: As an action, spend 1 spell point to create a protective ward around a campsite or room. The ward prevents the entry of spirits and curses for 24 hours. Additionally, you cannot be spied upon by other creatures while in the ward.
  • Commune with Spirits: As an action, spend 1 spell point to open your senses to the spirit world, allowing you to communicate with spirits and ancestors. You may ask up to three questions, to which the spirits respond according to their knowledge and disposition.
  • Extended Possession: You can now possess a target from short range.
  • Residual Influence: After leaving a possessed body, the target remains under a minor influence. As your next half-action after possession, you can give one simple command (no more than five words) that the target feels compelled to obey as long as it brings them no harm.
  • Enhanced Memory Access: Gain the ability to dive deeper into the host’s memories, accessing significant past events or secrets the host is aware of. Alternatively, you can create memories as an action on your next turn, spending 1 spell point. If the memories are not feasible, the host will not accept the memory.
  • Defensive Possession: As a reaction to an ally taking damage, possess them to reduce the damage by half. You remain in possession until the end of their next turn.
Nightwhisper

Your magic is subtle and elusive, casting spells that cloak and reveal, hiding allies or exposing enemies. Your Stealth Check is your spellcasting check. You have Spell points equal to your Stealth Check. Regain 1 spell point on a Press On, all on a long rest. Gain an additional spell point each time you successfully move undetected past enemies or eavesdrop on a conversation without being noticed.

Mirage Cloak

Wrap yourself in an illusion as an action, altering your appearance or becoming invisible until the end of your next turn. You can also change small aspects of your appearance at will, such as eye color, hairstyle, or even the pattern of your clothing, perfect for blending in or standing out.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

  • Hallucinatory Terrain: Change the appearance of your surroundings, creating strategic advantages or hiding escape routes. Alternatively, create a large-scale illusion that mimics a battle or a natural phenomenon, causing chaos among enemies.
  • Mimicry Mastery: Perfectly imitate sounds and voices you have heard, from the chirping of birds to the voice of a local guard, adding a layer of deception to your illusions.
  • Phantasmal Performer: Summon illusory figures to perform simple tasks, like playing instruments, juggling, or even acting out small scenes. There can be up to 6, and they can do simple tasks, but these cannot attack and have no physical form.
  • Phantom Banquet: As an action, create the illusion of a lavish feast, complete with the appearance and aroma of delicious food. The food is edible and delicious, and people feel satiated during the meal but are hungry 1 hour later.
  • Disorienting Mirage: As an Off-Action (Reaction), create a rapidly shifting illusion around a target enemy, causing their attack to have disadvantage.
  • Spectral Chains: As an action, summon illusory chains to bind an enemy, potentially causing them to believe they are restrained and reducing their movement or actions for a turn. They must make an Intellect Check to escape or remain pinned by the chains.
  • Psychic Backlash: Imbue your illusions with a psychic sting, causing enemies who touch them to suffer[[1d4]]psychic damage.
  • Illusive Step: As an action, teleport a short-range distance, leaving an illusion where you stood until the end of your next turn.
  • Invisible Maze: As an action, trap a creature in an invisible labyrinth, challenging them to escape. They must make an Intellect or Observation Check to escape, realizing it is an illusion on a success.
  • Phantom Voices: As a reaction, cast whispers around a target with a spellcasting check, distracting or misdirecting them on a success, causing disadvantage on a check.
Mightforge

Your magic embodies raw power and force, casting spells that enhance physical might or crush obstacles. Your Strength Check is your spellcasting check. You have Spell points equal to your Strength Check. Regain 1 spell point on a Press On, all on a long rest. Gain an additional spell point each time you triumph in a feat of strength or win a physical contest.

Armored Mage

You suffer no penalties from wearing armor.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

  • Forceful Barrier: As a half-action, conjure a barrier of pure kinetic energy that grants [[1d6]] armor to yourself and an ally within short range. This armor lasts for 1 minute.
  • Stone Skin: Gain +5 Armor and +5 Wounds.
  • Titan's Might: Increase your physical might, allowing you to lift, push, or break objects deemed impossible for ordinary beings.
  • Thunderous Leap: Utilize your strength to perform a powered leap that causes a shockwave upon landing. As an action, jump to a location within medium range, dealing [[1d6]] thunder damage to all enemies within reach range of the landing spot.
  • Berserker's Mage: Channel your strength into a furious battle rage. As an action, enter a rage for 1 minute, granting you +5 to attack checks with melee weapons and +10 armor until the end of the minute.
  • Earthquake Stomp: As an action, slam the ground with your foot, creating a localized earthquake around you. Enemies within short range must succeed on a Strength check or be knocked prone and take 8 bludgeoning damage, halving the damage per success.
  • Mana Wrest: When engaging in a feat of strength or a contest of physical prowess, you can channel your mana to gain advantage on the check. This ability requires the expenditure of 1 spell point and can be activated as a free action.
  • Mending: As an action, touch a piece of armor and repair it for +5 armor per spell point used.
  • Iron Will: You have advantage on checks, spells, and circumstances where your mental resilience is challenged by feats of endurance or psychological strain that would impose control over you or inflict a Cognitive condition.
  • Intuitive Dodge: Your keen instincts allow you to evade danger. once per long rest, if an attack is about to hit you, it does not.
Ravager

Your spells are born of the earth and the instinct to endure, casting spells that protect, nourish, or summon nature's fury. Your Survival Check is your spellcasting check. You have Spell points equal to your Survival Check. Regain 1 spell point on a Press On, all on a long rest. Gain an additional spell point each time you successfully survive from poison or disease, or find food or water in the wilderness.

Mana Hunger

Gain a resource of Mana Hunger that starts at 0. When this reaches 10, you enter Mana Overdrive that lasts for 1 minute, setting your Mana Hunger back to 0. While in Mana Overdrive, your spells cost -3 less, but the strain of the spells causes 1 psychic damage per cast. On a long rest, you can reduce your Mana Hunger by [[1d4]].

Mana Drain

As an off-action, you can tap deeper into your inner reservoir, gaining 3 temporary spell points that last until the end of your next turn but gain 2 Mana Hunger.

Progression

You may freely select talent progression steps in any order. With each step, gain a +1 bonus to any one of your checks, though no check can exceed a maximum of 15.

  • Mana Ravager: Harnessing the primal energies, your spell base damage is [[1d6]] , and while in Mana Overdrive, it becomes [[2d6]].
  • Mana Shield: A surge of protective energy courses through your veins. Gain +10 armor when entering Mana Overdrive.
  • Mana Demon: When you enter Mana Overdrive, get a +2 to checks and damage of your spells.
  • Mana Siphon: Hitting with a spell restores 1 spell point, and while in Mana Overdrive, you regain +1 wound.
  • Overdrive Pulse: When entering Mana Overdrive, enemies within reach range take[[1d4]]elemental damage.
  • Ravaging Echo: Gain +1 to check and damage when you cast a spell on the same target, and while in Mana Overdrive, gain +3 to the check and damage.
  • Overdrive Push: When entering Mana Overdrive, enemies within reach range must make a Strength check or be pushed 10ft.
  • Mana Cascade: When you make a critical hit, your spells deal triple damage.
  • Overdrive Capacity: You can choose to enter Mana Overdrive when your Mana Hunger reaches 5.
  • Hunger Spender: If you take the Injured Condition, you can spend your Mana Hunger and heal for your total of that resource, but you take the Coughing Condition.

Species

Species Information

The world is home to a vast array of intelligent beings, collectively known as species. These individuals enrich the realm with their unique cultures, abilities, and perspectives.

Your choice of species determines not only your character's traits and capabilities but also their place in the world. Species bring their individuality to the forefront, creating an infinite variety of stories and roles.

Roleplaying Freedom

Species offer limitless possibilities for crafting your character’s journey. Your choices define who your character becomes.

Equality and Representation

The term "species" reflects inclusivity and mutual respect, acknowledging the value of all intelligent life.

Species and Identity

Each species' story is shaped by their choices and experiences rather than by inherent traits.

Languages

In Shek, language transcends mere conversation, embedding itself in the fabric of culture, magic, and technology.

Imperial

The common tongue, bridging diverse cultures. Essential for diplomacy and trade.

Orcish/Elvish

Accents and dialects connecting speakers to Orc and Elf heritage.

Naech

Includes predator, prey, and fliers dialects for communicating with animals.

Dealig

A dark, mysterious language of Oreadlis, crucial for dealing with otherworldly entities.

Etheros

The elemental language for summoning and commanding forces like fire and stone.

Night

The language of the undead and nocturnal entities, essential for necromancy.

Clunk

The mechanical tongue, used to interact with constructs and technology.

Yar

Seafarer’s language for navigation and maritime lore.

Drak

The draconic language, granting access to dragon magic and ancient wisdom.

Holy

The celestial language for divine magic and celestial beings.

Jotun

The language of giants, offering insights into their ancient culture.

Species Options

Humans

Humans are a rare but influential creatures, known for their leadership within the empire. Their presence evokes a mix of respect, fear, and awe, making them synonymous with power and governance. Over time, "human" has broadened to include other humanoids, yet "true humans" hold a distinct status, marked by their uncommon appearance and significant roles. Encountering a human in casual settings, away from their typical authoritative contexts, can be surprising and leads to whispered speculations. This duality of reverence and suspicion underscores the complex legacy of humans in Shek, making them a focal point of intrigue and influence in a world rich with diverse beings.

Primarch

Primarchs

Primarchs, often referred to as "True Humans" by some cultures, represent a rare and enigmatic strain of humanity that embodies the full spectrum of human potential and ambition. They are distinguished by their commanding presence and potent influence, often occupying positions of power where their natural authority can sway the will of others.

Feared and revered in equal measure, their very existence shapes the course of history, with their actions often heralding significant change and leaving an enduring legacy in their wake. Despite their rarity, Primarchs reflect the diversity inherent to humanity, encompassing a vast array of cultural, philosophical, and moral leanings.

Average Size

5-6 ft

Lifespan

60-90 years

Language

Imperial

Diet

Omnivore

Rarity

Very Rare

Feature

  • Command: As an action, make a contested Influence Check targeting an intelligent creature you can see within short range. On a success, the creature will follow a single-word command until the start of their turn, to the best of its ability, as long as the command doesn't directly result in harm to the creature.
    • Sample Words:
      • Obey: Move toward you by the shortest route.
      • Discard: Drop whatever the target is holding.
      • Retreat: Move away from you by the fastest means.
      • Submit: Fall prone until the end of the next turn.
Changeling

Changelings

Changelings are rare and mysterious creatures, often misunderstood due to their supernatural origins and extraordinary abilities. They are the result of ancient interference by fey, fiendish, or otherworldly beings, who swapped their progeny with human children. This heritage ties them deeply to chaotic realms, giving them the unique ability to alter their physical appearance.

Changelings have a strange and fascinating presence in the world. Their ability to shift their form allows them to adapt to almost any situation, but it also alienates them from others. This power often leads to them being both feared and sought after, with some becoming spies, diplomats, or performers, while others are wrongly associated with criminal or deceitful activities.

Average Size

5-6 ft

Lifespan

60-90 years

Language

Imperial

Diet

Omnivore

Rarity

Very Rare

Changeling Options

Elemental

In the heart of the world's wild frontiers, where nature’s forces rage unchecked, the Elemental Changelings were born. Their origins are the stuff of ancient myths, tales of the world's formation and the spirits that shaped it.

It is said that an Elemental Changeling can listen to the whispers of the winds, converse with the babbling brooks, and coax the very mountains to shift. Their ceremonies are spectacles of elemental mastery, where fire and water dance, stone and air embrace, and the spirits of nature join in a harmonious chorus.

Features:

  • Faceshift: As an action, shift your facial structure into that of another creature you have studied within the past 24 hours, know intimately, or have loyalty with.
  • Elemental Immunity: once per long rest, as an action, gain immunity to an elemental damage type for 1 minute.
Vozian

Beneath the veil of the mortal realm, in places tainted by darkness and flame, the Vozian Changelings emerged. Their genesis is intertwined with tales of forbidden pacts and infernal bargains.

Now, these changelings walk the world bearing both the gift and curse of their infernal heritage. With the ability to assume forms that mirror the nightmares of many, they are both feared and revered.

Features:

  • Dreadful Faceshift: Shift into a horrifying visage or a monster. Make an Influence Check on an intelligent creature within range. On success, the target gains the Fear condition and immunity to this effect for a time.
  • Vozian Defense: As a half-action, assume a defensive stance. The next time you take damage, halve the total and exit the stance.
Nemuri

Between the bounds of reality and the vast expanse of the Dreamsea, the Nemuri Changelings found their place. Their lineage traces back to ancient times when the boundaries between realms were thin, and the Dreamsea would often spill into the waking world.

With an ethereal grace, these changelings possess the unique ability to flit between the tangible and intangible, making them enigmatic figures in the world's legends.

Features:

  • Intangible Shifting: Shift your facial structure into another creature's form within the past 24 hours, know intimately, or have loyalty with.
  • Phasing: Become intangible until the start of your next turn. While intangible, you are also invisible.
Dwarves

Dwarves

Dwarves are a steadfast and industrious species group, renowned for their resilience, adaptability, and unparalleled craftsmanship. With deep cultural roots and a long history, Dwarves thrive in diverse environments both above and below ground. They are known for their expertise in stonework, mining, and metallurgy, as well as their ability to create intricate structures and durable artifacts.

Historically, Dwarves were integral members of a larger empire that united many species groups. However, they broke away following a dispute between their ruler, the Tyrant King, and the Emperor of the empire. This pivotal split shaped Dwarven culture, fostering an enduring sense of independence and self-reliance that continues to influence their society.

Dwarves are a common sight in underground cities, where their communities are structured around craftsmanship, trade, and a rigid adherence to tradition. Despite their inclination toward self-sufficiency, Dwarves are far from isolationist. Their goods and skills are highly sought after by other species, making them key contributors to the world’s economy and culture.

Average Size

3-5 ft

Lifespan

200-400 years

Language

Imperial (Dwarga)

Diet

Omnivore, Dirt & Soil

Rarity

Common below ground

Dwarf Options

Hill Dwarves

Hill Dwarves are a rugged and adaptable subrace of Dwarves who have embraced life above ground. Spending much of their time under the open sky, they are known for their dark, sun-kissed skin and thick black hair, often tied back or braided. Hill Dwarves are practical and hardworking people, skilled in farming, stone-cutting, and brewing.

Features:

  • Stonecast Liver: As an off-action, if you are missing wounds, drink any alcoholic beverage to regain[[1d4]]wounds but gain the confused condition for 1 minute.
Mountain Dwarves

Mountain Dwarves are the traditionalists of their kind, born and raised in the massive peaks and deep caverns beneath the surface. They are natural warriors and master craftsmen, deeply tied to their subterranean homes where they mine precious gems and metals.

Features:

  • Poison Drinker: Immune to poison effects.
  • Stone Skin: As a half-action, gain +5 armor until the end of your next turn.
Flamebeard Dwarves

Flamebeard Dwarves are a fiery and enigmatic subrace, born deep within the volcanic regions of the Dwelfmire. Their molten environment has forged them into a unique people, with ashen skin and hair resembling living flames. As they age, some display glowing molten veins beneath their skin.

Features:

  • Molten Core: As an off-action, gain immunity to fire damage until the end of your next turn.
  • Heat Iron: As a half-action, give a weapon +3 fire damage for 1 minute.
Breaker Dwarves

Breaker Dwarves, a distinct lineage, have long resided in the depths of the Dwelfmire. Known for their pale skin and vivid red tattoos symbolizing status, they have a controversial legacy tied to practices of indentured servitude. While some Breakers seek redemption by abandoning their subterranean cities, others remain staunch traditionalists.

Features:

  • Breaker Gear: You have a Breaker Pistol (1-hand, medium range,[[1d4]]piercing damage) that automatically hits without a check.
Elves

Elves

Elves are a deeply adaptive group of species who evolve and adapt to their environments so thoroughly that they often become integral parts of the ecosystems they inhabit. Known for their grace, long lives, and connection to magic, Elves are a common thread in the folklore of many species, having played pivotal roles in the histories of others.

Once considered integral members of the ancient empire, Elves have, in more recent times, stepped away from their roles as caretakers of other species to focus on rediscovering their own identity and purpose. This withdrawal has allowed them to embrace their individuality, but it has also splintered their communities into distinct groups, each tied deeply to the environment or plane they inhabit.

Average Size

5-6 ft

Lifespan

200-400 years

Language

Imperial (Eln)

Diet

Omnivore, Vegetarian

Rarity

Common

Elven Options

Gloom Elves

Gloom Elves have adapted to life in shadowy and subterranean environments, where light is scarce. Those born deep underground possess dark, shadow-like skin and hair so white it resembles spider silk. Surface-dwelling Gloom Elves, however, have developed pastel hair colors that mirror the twilight skies of their woodland homes. Known for their keen senses, Gloom Elves are natural hunters and scouts, using their connection to the earth to detect unseen threats. Despite their somber appearance, they are fiercely loyal and resourceful people who value the bonds of community.

Features:

  • Poison Stinger: Unarmed strikes deal an additional [[1d4]] toxic damage.
  • Vibration Sense: Your feet are sensitive to ground vibrations. As an off-action, you can detect the approach of any creature making contact with the ground within medium range, provided they are in contact with the same ground.
Forest Elves

Forest Elves consider themselves the truest connection to the original elven lineage, living harmoniously with nature and the Feywild. Their homes are often hidden deep within vast forests, where trees not only provide shelter but act as allies, moving to protect their elven caretakers. Forest Elves are graceful and serene, their songs and rituals strengthening the bond between the natural world and their kind. They are often seen as guardians of nature, defending their homes and wildlife from outside threats with a fierceness that belies their delicate appearance.

Features:

  • Tree Step: Move into a tree and out of another within medium range as part of your movement.
  • Tree Speech: Speak Naech fluently, communicating easily with plants and animals.
Noble Elves

Also known as High Elves, Noble Elves pride themselves on their mastery of magic and their long-standing heritage as rulers and scholars. They once formed grand kingdoms in the Feywild, their courts steeped in arcane tradition and timeless beauty. Though many remain in the Feywild, some Noble Elves have returned to the prime material plane, eager to reclaim their dominance over mortal kingdoms. Noble Elves are graceful and regal, often exuding an air of superiority, but their intellect and magical prowess make them valuable allies.

Features:

  • Mind Spike: As an action, deal[[1d4]]psychic damage to a creature within medium range on a successful Intellect check.
Eclipse Elves

Eclipse Elves are enigmatic beings born in the Eclipse, a shadowy realm that lies between worlds. Their smoky, ethereal appearance reflects the nature of their homeland, where light and darkness intertwine. These elves are natural wanderers between dimensions, often acting as guides, spies, or guardians of planar boundaries. Their connection to shadow and their ability to move unseen make them mysterious figures in the eyes of other species groups. Despite their otherworldly demeanor, Eclipse Elves are deeply thoughtful and often wrestle with the duality of their existence.

Features:

  • Eclipse Born: As a half-action, gain the invisible condition while in darkness until the end of your next turn.
Vozian Elves

Vozian Elves are a dark and eerie Options shaped by their proximity to demons, devils, and the harsh ashlands of the far north. Their violet-toned skin and sinister aura make them feared and misunderstood by many. Vozian Elves often harness twisted magic, reflecting the suffering and chaos they have endured. Their diet and lifestyle are equally unsettling, having evolved to draw sustenance from live creatures to experience their suffering. Despite this grim exterior, some Vozian Elves use their dark magic to protect or guide, proving that their nature is not always defined by malevolence.

Special Diet: The diet of the vozian elves has significantly changed from that of the ancestors. They have adapted to taking in alive creatures to feel the suffering as they eat.

Features:

  • Diet: Vozian Elves consume live creatures to feel their suffering.
  • Vozian Blast: As an action, deal[[1d4]]psychic damage to a creature within medium range on a successful Spirit check.
Water Elves

Water Elves are amphibious beings who have adapted to life near and in the water. With gills that allow them to breathe both air and water, they are natural swimmers and divers. These elves often form close-knit communities with aquatic races like merfolk, living in harmony with the seas and rivers they call home. Known for their calm and fluid personalities, Water Elves often carry magical water from their homelands, using it to protect and heal. Their connection to the tides and their mastery of water magic make them invaluable in maritime endeavors.

Features:

  • Mana Water: Travel with a magical jug of water that can be manipulated magically. If broken, the water is lost.
  • Water Armor: At the start of your turn, gain 1 armor (max 5 from this source).
Nemuri Elves

Nemuri Elves are ethereal beings who reside in the Dreamsea. Their pale, nearly translucent skin and shimmering silver or gold hair give them a ghostly appearance. Nemuri Elves are deeply connected to the magic of dreams, often influencing the subconscious minds of others. They are gentle and enigmatic, moving effortlessly between the waking world and the realm of dreams. Nemuri Elves are often seen as spiritual guides, helping others confront their fears or explore hidden desires within their dreams. However, their dreamlike nature can make them seem distant or otherworldly.

Features:

  • Ethereal Movement: Gain the intangible condition until the end of your next turn as an action.
  • Dreamspeaker: See into and influence creatures’ dreams until the dreamer notices you.
Fungal Elves

Fungal Elves are unusual species that have adapted to life within dense fungal networks. Their bodies are often adorned with moss, lichen, and mushrooms, forming a symbiotic relationship with their environment. These elves possess a unique connection to the fungal world, communicating with the network around them and drawing strength from it. They are quiet and contemplative, valuing the slow, interconnected growth of their fungal homes. Though they can appear eerie to outsiders, Fungal Elves are deeply protective of their ecosystems and willing to spread their influence to preserve balance.

Features:

  • Fungal Connection: Communicate with fungi through a unique form of the Naech language.
  • Spore Burst: As an action, release a burst of spores from their body, creatures within reach range of the spore burst must make a Survival check or take the Confused condition until the end of their next turn.
Breaker Elves

In the dimly lit caverns deep below the world's surface, the Breaker Elves, or Gloom Elves, have carved a niche alongside the industrious Breaker Dwarves. As the epochs passed, these elves have come to share more than just the subterranean territories with the dwarves; they've adopted the Breaker mindset, embracing the intricate technologies and complex societal structures of their dwarven neighbors.

Long ago, the ancestors of the Breaker Elves sought refuge in the underground realms to escape a cataclysmic event on the surface. Over the centuries, their physiology adapted to the darkness, resulting in the evolution of their distinctive dark skin, which seamlessly blends with the shadows. Their ethereal hair, reminiscent of delicate spider silk, is a testament to their life away from the sun. The Breaker Elves, with their blend of elven grace and Breaker ingenuity, are a testament to the adaptability of life, proving that even in the harshest of environments, beauty and innovation can flourish. Their eyes are adapted to see in the infrared spectrum, allowing them to perceive temperature differences in their environment, which can be especially handy in detecting living beings or working machines

Features:

  • Echo Locator: Use echolocation as an off-action to detect obstacles and creatures within medium range even around cover and down hallways.
  • Pastel Illumination: Cause your bioluminescent hair to glow, shedding dim light in reach range as a half-action.
Gnomes

Gnomes

Gnomes are an inventive and endlessly curious group of species, known for their boundless imagination and the risks they often take in pursuit of knowledge. Once thriving in the Feywild, Gnomes were celebrated for their ingenuity and eccentricity. However, their curiosity took a dark turn with the rise of the Tinker Gnomes, who, in their pursuit of magical power, began harvesting dryad hearts to create cores for powerful constructs.

When the atrocities came to light, the Feywild itself, under the guidance of Mother Nature, banished all Gnomes, marking them as exiles. Though the actions of the Tinker Gnomes were the cause, the punishment extended to the entire Gnomish people, forcing them to leave their home plane forever. This banishment left a deep mark on Gnomish culture, splitting them into those who seek redemption and balance with nature and those who fully embrace invention and progress, regardless of the cost.

Despite their complicated past, Gnomes are fiercely determined to make their mark on the world. They are often seen as visionaries, tinkering with magical devices, crafting intricate machinery, and pushing the boundaries of what is possible. While many Gnomes resent the mistakes of their ancestors, others see their exile as a challenge to prove that their ingenuity can benefit the world without repeating the sins of the past.

Average Size

3-4 ft

Lifespan

120-200 years

Language

Imperial (Complicated Elvish)

Diet

Omnivore, Vegetarian

Rarity

Somewhat Common

Gnome Options

Tinker

The banishment never disturbed their work. They continue with experiments that have helped and hurt creatures all throughout the world. Their homelands are often sprawling cities of moving parts, practically living traps.

Tinker-ish

You start with an interesting invention that was yours or one of your family’s creations. You keep it with you at all times, and it is very important. Choose from the following list:

  • The Impossible Pocket: A pocket 6 inches wide that can fit up to 100 lbs.
  • Light Switch: Flick the switch to turn lights on or off.
  • The Chemical Transmuter: Pour in one potion and get out another. Make a luck check to determine if it gets better or worse.
  • Tikky Tim: A clockwork little guy (PL 1) that can be repaired as an action.
  • Temporary Teleport: Click the device to teleport up to medium range for 1 minute. Afterward, you are violently teleported back.
  • Tinker Wings: Allow you to fly equal to your movement, but you fall to the ground at the end of your turn.
Gloom

Gloom Gnomes are fun-loving creatures that have tried to find a new home in the Dwelfmire since they left the warm grassy mountains of the Fey. Wherever they go feels like home to them and others around.

Quality Comforts

  • When you and your party Press On, give everyone a +1 to anything they recover or repair.
  • When you stop somewhere, you can create a comfortable environment, increasing rest healing and safety. It is unlikely that creatures will invade your space, and if they do, they are unlikely to attack.
Vozian

Vozian Gnomes are gnomes that have formed a pact with infernal entities, granting them increased power and abilities. Known for their reddish skin and fiery red eyes, they are often feared and shunned by other gnomes and races for their association with the infernal realm.

Infernal Pact

  • Infernal Summoning: As an action, summon a PL 2 demon that must follow your commands, though reluctantly. It remains for 1 minute or until killed.
Nemuri

Nemuri Gnomes have formed a connection with the Dreamsea, granting them increased abilities in magic and Dreamsea manipulation. Known for their ethereal appearance and glowing eyes, they are sought after for their abilities in divination and Nemuri travel.

Nemuri Connection

  • Telepathically connect with a creature after 1 hour of linking. Afterward, you can always communicate with this creature regardless of distance or plane. You can only link to one creature at a time.
  • Nemuri Manipulation: Gain +2 Spell Points.
Kleinkind

Kleinkind

Small in stature but grand in spirit, the Kleinkind are a species as cozy as a well-worn quilt and as surprising as a jack-in-the-box. Often referred to as "Halflings" by outsiders, these delightful people weave a narrative claiming they were the first intelligent beings to grace the planet. Whether this is true or just a tale spun over a warm mug of cider, the Kleinkind hold their belief with pride (and no small amount of charm).

The Kleinkind's hallmark is their love of community and comfort. Their villages are havens of merriment, where doors are always open, feasts are abundant, and every stranger is a friend waiting to be made. Their lives are painted with warmth and laughter, their hearths glowing as brightly as their spirits. But not all Kleinkind are content to stay within the snug borders of their idyllic enclaves. Some feel the pull of the road, a wanderlust that drives them to become Barnstormers—restless travelers who bring joy, stories, and just a touch of chaos wherever they go.

Physically, Kleinkind are marvels of density. Standing no taller than 2 feet, they are far heavier than their size suggests, with compact musculature that makes them unexpectedly sturdy. A 1-foot Kleinkind can weigh up to 60 pounds, leading to many a startled adventurer who underestimated their strength. Despite their heft, they move with surprising nimbleness, like a stone rolling downhill—steady and unstoppable.

Average Size

1-2 ft

Lifespan

60-90 years

Language

Imperial

Diet

Comfort food

Rarity

Somewhat Common

Features

  • Pleasant Aura: Regale a creature with a story for 1 minute. Afterward, you and the creature gain +2 loyalty with one another. Creatures with positive loyalty toward you cannot willingly attack you.
  • Warmbones: Your connection to home and hearth exudes an aura of calm, making others feel safe.
  • Barnstormer: When traveling for more than 1 week without settling, gain advantage on Luck checks until you remain in one place for 1 week. During this time, you lose the effects of Warmbones.
Orcs

Orcs

The Orcs are a powerful and resilient group of species native to the Orclands, a vast and diverse region that spans thick jungles, arid deserts, and icy mountains. This variety of environments has given rise to distinct cultural and physical adaptations among the Orcs, with each region producing unique traits and skills.

Orcs from the dense jungles are known for their durable skin and natural agility, moving effortlessly through thick vegetation. Desert Orcs, with their dark black skin and lean, athletic builds, have adapted to survive the harsh, sun-scorched sands. Mountain Orcs, large and pale, are built to endure the freezing cold and thin air of the peaks. Despite these regional differences, all Orcs share a defining physical feature: their prominent tusks, which once served practical purposes such as digging for food but now stand as a proud symbol of their strength and heritage.

Beyond their territorial prowess, Orcs are innovators and creators, blending their need for survival and strength with ingenuity. Their culture values exploration and the mastery of their environment, leading to groundbreaking contributions in navigation, agriculture, and written communication.

Average Size

6-8 ft

Lifespan

60-90 years

Language

Imperial (Orkid)

Diet

Omnivore, Vegetarian

Rarity

Common

Orc Options

Desert Orcs

Desert Orcs used stone-moving magics and hard work to create stone dome structures in which they lived as large packs. Leadership was attained through combat, with the leader needing to fight everyone to calm disputes. Desert Orcs prefer to fight in large numbers with several creatures attacking at once.

Features:

  • Desert Striker: Gain +2 to Unarmed Attack checks and damage.
Mountain Orcs

In the mountains of the Orclands, the pale orcs reign supreme. They possess a mastery of stone and metal that rivals even the dwarves. Rarely seen outside their mountain temples, Mountain Orcs are known for their impressive architectural feats and unmatched skill in working with stone and metal. When they leave their lands, they are magically bound to secrecy by powerful tattoos.

Features:

  • Weapon Connection: Gain +2 to Attack Checks and Damage with weapons.
Jungle Orcs

The Green Jungle Orc is the most prevalent Orc option throughout the world. These tribes originally roamed and controlled the Orclands, being the first to develop a written language. Starting with knotted threads, their language evolved into scarification and tattoos, used for tracking time, marking landmarks, and agricultural purposes.

Due to their diet of superfoods, Jungle Orcs grew to impressive sizes and developed the ability to shrug off pain and maintain limitless reserves of energy. These traits allowed them to build an empire based on strength, stamina, and strategic thinking. They are fierce warriors and skilled strategists who once controlled vast portions of the Orclands.

Features:

  • Rushing Charge: If you move toward a creature within 20 ft and make an attack, gain advantage on the attack.
Maldios Orcs

Orcs are not free from Vozian influence. Legends say that the first Orc born was the first Orc turned. Maldios resides in the infernal planes as a mad guardian of the sands. Descendants of his infernal heritage, or those tainted by the infernal, possess bright orange skin and fire-like glistening eyes.

Features:

  • Infernal Skin: As a reaction to getting hit with a melee attack, deal [[1d4]] Vozian damage to the creature that hit you.
Oceanic Orcs

Oceanic Orcs are a rare group of Orcs native to the Dreamsea. Known for their ethereal appearance, they possess semi-translucent, glowing skin and unearthly bright eyes. Their elongated limbs and fingers allow them to move gracefully in the weightlessness of the Dreamsea.

Peaceful and spiritual by nature, Oceanic Orcs communicate with spirits of the dead and are sought after as guides and healers. Their ability to navigate the Dreamsea grants them access to ancient knowledge and wisdom. They can manifest Nemuri energy into solid forms to create weapons and armor.

Features:

  • Nemuri Manipulation: As an enhance action, imbue a weapon with Dreamsea water, changing its damage type to water and dealing an additional +4 damage for 1 minute.
Core Bound

Core Bound

Known as Core Bound or The Forged, these entities were originally crafted by gnome tinkerers who transferred dryads from their natural habitats into engineered cores. This fusion of natural essence and mechanical engineering gave rise to sentient beings encased in armor, powered by the very core of nature itself. While they were initially used in warfare due to their ability to be reborn in new armors if the core remained intact, modern Core Bound constructs lead full lives, capable of all human-like functions including emotional connections. Efforts continue among scholars to unlock and reclaim memories from the cores that might still linger from previous incarnations.

Average Size

3-9 ft

Lifespan

60 per cycle

Language

Imperial

Diet

Fuel Source

Rarity

Rare

Construct Options

Arcane Core

Arcane Core constructs are powered by pure magical energy, their cores brimming with arcane power. These constructs are often adorned with intricate runes and symbols etched into their bodies, marking their deep connection to magic. Designed to wield potent magical abilities, Arcane Core constructs possess heightened intellect and an unparalleled understanding of the arcane arts.

Features:

  • Arcane Core: Convert your total wounds into armor at the end of character creation. Your armor regenerates 1 point per hour until fully restored. As a half-action, you can make a crafting check to repair an additional +5 armor once every hour. If your armor drops below 0, you enter a dormant state and cannot act or respond. Armor continues to regenerate in this state. Removing the core in a dormant state resets personality and erases memories. If the core is damaged in this state, it cannot be repaired.
  • Fuel Source - Mana Crystals: Dense stones imbued with pure magical energy, mined from regions thick with arcane power.
Dryad Core

Dryad Core constructs are imbued with the life essence of nature itself, granting them a deep connection to the natural world. Their bodies are often entwined with vines and leaves, and their agility and perception make them as swift and adaptive as the forests they resemble.

Features:

  • Dryad Core: Convert your total wounds into armor at the end of character creation. Your armor regenerates 1 point per hour until fully restored. As an off-action, you can make a crafting check to repair an additional [[1d10]] armor once every hour. If your armor drops below 0, you enter a dormant state and cannot act or respond. Armor continues to regenerate in this state. Removing the core in a dormant state resets personality and erases memories. If the core is damaged in this state, it cannot be repaired.
  • Ancient Knowledge: Gain advantage on Intellect (History) checks, reflecting the ancient wisdom within your core.
  • Fuel Source - Photosynthate Gel: A biologically engineered substance that replicates the effects of photosynthesis in plants.
Vozian Core

Vozian Core constructs are powered by infernal energy, their cores infused with the smoldering flames of the damned. Their bodies are often scorched and cracked, with flickering embers dancing across their frames, a testament to the dark power they wield.

Features:

  • Vozian Core: Convert your total wounds into armor at the end of character creation. Your armor regenerates 1 point per hour until fully restored. As an action, you can make a crafting check to repair an additional +10 armor once every hour. If your armor drops below 0, you enter a dormant state and cannot act or respond. Armor continues to regenerate in this state. Removing the core in a dormant state resets personality and erases memories. If the core is damaged in this state, it cannot be repaired.
  • Fuel Source - Ashes of the Damned: The cremated remains of powerful undead creatures, which continue to smolder with residual life force.
Realmsplit

Realmsplit species are unique beings born of the union between humans and entities from other planes of existence. These extraordinary individuals inherit traits and abilities from both their human heritage and their otherworldly lineage, making them distinct and powerful in their own right. Whether they are descendants of celestial beings or infernal entities, Realmsplit characters possess a fascinating blend of qualities that set them apart from others.

Ensuri

Ensuri

The Ensuri are a mystical and enigmatic species, born from the union of humans and the primordial forces of the elements. Tracing their lineage back to the dawn of existence, the Ensuri embody the fierce power and untamed beauty of the natural world. Some among them hail from ancient families, their bloodlines intertwined with elemental spirits through sacred rites and ancient pacts. Others are the product of transformation, individuals who were altered by profound elemental events, forever changed by their exposure to raw elemental power.

With appearances as diverse as the elements themselves, the Ensuri possess traits reflective of their elemental heritage—skin that shimmers like the surface of a lake under moonlight for those of water lineage, or eyes that flicker with the undying flame of their fire ancestors. They are beings of both creation and destruction, capable of wielding their elemental powers with a natural ease that belies their human origins.

Average Size

5-6 ft

Lifespan

60-90 years

Language

Imperial, Etheros

Diet

Elemental

Rarity

Uncommon

Ensuri Options

Air

The Air Ensuri are ethereal wanderers, drifting wherever the winds of fate carry them. With their airy conversations and light-hearted demeanor, they are the quintessential free spirits. Drawn to the mystical and powerful, they often find themselves in the company of dragons and dragonborn, believing that the wind is the breath of Khalas. Their culture is rich with music and dance that mimic the movements of the wind, and their nomadic tribes are known for their storytelling and vibrant festivals. They prefer light, airy foods such as soufflés, whipped cream, and fresh fruits, embodying their connection to the sky and freedom.

Features:

  • One with the Wind: You have a fly speed equal to your movement speed but you must end your turn on solid ground or else fall to solid ground at the end of your turn.
Stone

The Stone Ensuri are the epitome of strength and stability. With skin like stone, gems, or crystals, they are rugged and resilient, embodying the essence of the earth. They are hardworking, loyal, and deeply connected to the land. Their culture values craftsmanship and endurance, often reflected in their elaborate stone carvings and architecture. Their communities are built into mountains and caves, creating breathtaking underground cities. They consume hearty, mineral-rich foods like root vegetables and hearty stews, reminiscent of the sustenance required by miners and laborers, symbolizing their grounded nature.

Features:

  • Stone Glide: You can submerge into stone, rock, or stone like water as an action and have half movement speed while submerged in the rock. You can be heard and felt in the stone but not seen unless you bring yourself to the surface.
Fire

The Fire Ensuri are passionate and fierce, with a fiery temperament to match their scorching abilities. Hailing from the Crumbling Void, they live alongside powerful fire elementals and are led by an immortal fire giant. Their culture is one of strength and defiance, celebrating fire in all its forms through grand festivals and rituals. They are known for their stunning heat dances and pyrotechnic displays. Their diet consists of spicy, grilled, and roasted foods, including charred meats and curries, reflecting their burning intensity and zest for life.

Features:

  • Fire Control: If there is a nearby fire you can control the flame by making it larger up to two times, smaller, or dissipating it. You can bring the flame to you and hold it in your hands. Additionally, when you deal heat damage, deal an additional +3 damage.
  • Fire Immune: As an action you gain fire damage immunity until the end of your next turn and gain a fire shield of +3.
Water

The Water Ensuri are fluid and adaptable, with a serene and calming presence. Their semi-translucent skin shimmers like the surface of a clear lake. They live in harmony with the aquatic world, often residing in underwater cities made of coral and glass. Their culture revolves around the ebb and flow of the tides, with ceremonies and traditions tied to the lunar cycles.
